story:
Summary

GraphLock is a patent-pending scientific & graphing calculator app with lockdown mode capability and classroom monitoring.  While in lockdown mode, students can only use the calculator app making it secure and ideal for use in high school and college classrooms and on exams. Lockdown mode means just that - no calls, texts, internet or other apps! 

Hello, my name is Mallory Dyer and I am a Math Professor and the Co-Founder/CEO of GraphLock. Over the last couple of years, I have seen how the rise in the cost of education has negatively affected my students. There was always one big barrier that many of them had to face - the cost of a scientific & graphing calculator! This calculator is typically required for any algebra or higher math class both in high school and college. Almost all college students will need this calculator for at least one math class to graduate and get their degree. The calculator allowed during exams now costs $100 or more, and students are expected and required to have one.  Many parents and students cannot afford $100 on a calculator while paying tuition, room and board, and other daily expenses, leading to inequality in the classroom. This creates an environment where not all students have the same opportunities to excel.

  •   It’s heartbreaking to watch students struggle and fail because they cannot  afford the tool they need. 
  •   The students WANT to learn and do well in math. 
  •   It’s frustrating as a teacher to witness students give up and lose  confidence in math 
  •   I’ve seen students drop out of class because they did not have a $100  scientific & graphing calculator and could not do the higher level math.
  •   In this day and age, students shouldn't be forced to spend an outrageous  amount of money on the same calculator I used over 15  years ago! 

  So I set out and was determined to find a solution to help students    everywhere!

 


Meet GraphLock – the $5 Solution. Woop woop!

We are so passionate about helping students and giving every student an equal opportunity to excel in the math classroom. Our goal is to get a scientific and graphing calculator into the hand of every student. You can help us with this endeavor and sponsor a student today!  

During this campaign, anyone that donates $5 or more, will be able to provide low income students or schools a free GraphLock download or you can pre-order the app for yourself! 

It’s a Scientific Calculator.  It’s a Graphing Calculator.  It's secure to use in class and on exams. For only $5.  GraphLock can be downloaded to smart phones, tablets, or computers.  

Currently, 86% of all college students now own a smartphone and 80% of high school students do. We have found that those who do not have own a phone, often have access to a tablet or computer at school.  One of our future goals is to team up and get  ahold of recycled devices to donate to students with the app downloaded right onto it! 

Teachers applaud.  Parents and students save money.  Every student has the same opportunity to reach their full potential in math. 

Finally!  With our lockdown mode, Teachers can have the peace of mind that their students are not being distracted by their phone or tablet. When the app is in lockdown mode, the students cannot access anything else on their phone – no calls, no texting, no social media, no internet (except an emergency call - just in case.)  Students will be able to use the same calculator at home, in class and on exams. Plus, they will never forget to bring it!!

Also, included in GraphLock is a classroom monitoring system allowing teachers to start and stop the lockdown mode all at the same time. So the teacher can simply set the lockdown for the length of the class and once it is over, all students have their phones back as soon as the timer goes off! How awesome is that?!

GraphLock was created by a teacher for a teacher.  The app is simple, effective, and useful. 

Parents save money by purchasing a $5 app (no batteries needed) instead of a $100 calculator!  Also, there is a parent version where parents can use the lockdown feature by putting their children's phone on “lockdown” allowing only the calculator to work; no texts, Snapchats, or Facebook!  This takes "homework time" to a whole new level and helps keep students focused. Fabulous!

Students have peace of mind because they can accomplish their academic goals by having the necessary tools for their mathematics/engineering classes all for the price of a cup of coffee! Plus they will be able to use the same calculator at home, in class and on exams from high school through college. And, they will never forget their calculator because it is right on their device!

Funds, Funds, Funds

The funds from this campaign will go directly towards: free downloads to low income students, marketing, and training. Our goal is to raise $25,000 to help over 5,000 students.  Our marketing is going to run through social media outlets and conferences to reach out to more schools and teachers. While our training is going to be online and on-site.  Any school that has over 650 downloads will receive on-site training from Co-Founder & CEO - Mallory Dyer.

Risks & Challenges

With every new endeavor comes risks and challenges.  While we cannot change the educational system overnight or the tools we use.  Or can we?  One of our biggest challenges will be getting the College Board & ACT to allow this as another accepted tool to use during examinations.  While we understand the importance of these exams and know the critical role they play in students’ futures, we are quite confident they will adopt GraphLock as an acceptable option.

Meet Team GraphLock!

Mallory Dyer, Co-Founder & CEO
Mallory is a Mathematics Professor at Central Arizona College since 2008 and won the National NISOD for Teaching Excellence Award.  She holds a Masters in Mathematics Education and a BA Mathematics from Arizona State University. She started out as an actuary only to realize teaching math was her passion! Mallory has been teaching ever since.  She absolutely loves giving students a new perspective on math and helping build their confidence. Her goal is to give every student the opportunity to excel and reach their full potential. Mallory knows  GraphLock will change lives!

Josh Dyer, Co-Founder & COO  
Josh has significant experience in financial software and operations.  He holds a BS in Business with a concentration in Finance from Arizona State University. Josh has moved on from the corporate world and is determined to help change the way technology is used in the classroom.

 Vijayant "VJ" Kanwar, Chief Product & Technology Officer
VJ holds a BS in Computer Science with a minor in Software Engineering from Mississippi State University.  At GraphLock, he is utilizing his passion and experience in Product-Program-Project Management, User Experience, Engineering, and Entrepreneurship to make it a success. He was a student in Mallory’s first calculus class!  You never know where life will take you!

Thank you!

Thank you so much for reading until the end!  We cannot thank you enough and are so excited that you share the love of education, the love of mathematics, the love of science, and the passion for helping others succeed. 

If you cannot donate at this time, no worries!  There are so many ways you can spread the word about GraphLock and our campaign! 

  1.   First, just share this post with everyone you know on your favorite social media platform! 
  2.   Second, share it on ALL of your social media platforms! 
  3.  Third, seriously, if you are reading this, let us know you are excited about GraphLock.  Visit us at graphlock.com

story:
Craduate: Know Everything you want to know about studying in USA!

A journey to study abroad, can be the most igniting phase of a student's life but unfortunately, more often than not it turns into a black hole.

Right from filling up the admission forms till landing in the foreign country, guidance is required at every stage but this guidance takes the shape of exploitation from counsellors.

What this scenario blatantly lacks, is a curated support system for students to experience seamless transition to this milestone in their life.

Selected at Boston University Accelerator, Craduate has now become a strategically curated platform to nurture and empower millions of dreams of studying abroad.

Dreams! That’s what a student’s journey starts with. At Craduate we strive to ignite these dreams and facilitate them with the best of services.

Indian Students struggling to get admission in a haloed US University. How often have you heard this story?

You must have heard this story quite often. The burgeoning talent pool and mind masters in India aim for gaining from the echelons of education based in the US. However, this story of grit, determination, ignited dreams and thriving passion, soon turns into a tale of challenges, confusion, predicaments and hassles.

It’s a shame that students, who should be concentrating only of their education, get entangled in administrative aggravations.

Here is where Craduate endeavours to make a difference!

Craduate as an enabling platform aims to make student experience amiable by

  • Seamless transitioning
  • Genuine Mentor support
  • Logistics convenience
  • Continual association

Craduate offers a holistic solution for the most important journey of a student's life.

Every endeavour starts with a volley of questions and the decision to study abroad is no exception. Craduate lays exact, all-encompassing, step by step guidelines for aspiring students to pursue their dream of acquiring degree from a reputed university in the US. This expertise stems from the fact that we understand each and every step in this journey, from the student's perspective as well as from the mentor's perspective.

We understand each and every phase of admission process and try to connect you to right mentors for your situation while suggesting you right set of questions to ask from your mentor.

There is a proliferation of agents and counsellors in India, yet the admission process is still a complex riddle for many students. This is because the entire process is not just unidirectional but multifaceted. Craduate provides and suggests (by analyzing historical data) aggregated information from multiple sources at one point to students.

The role of mentors is indispensable if a student is planning to pursue studies abroad. The learning experience from a mentor's guidance is unparalleled. However, the association with mentors usually depends on one’s personal connections. Craduate makes it all official, professional yet extremely warm. With the platform of Craduate, students can seek the right set of information for each step.

Craduate maintains alliance with students, alumnus, university representative from over 100 universities in the US.

Aspiring students can gain guidance from the rightly suited mentor as well as constantly stay in touch with the community through video chats, emails as well as direct conversations. There is nothing more empowering than enabling dreams and this is what makes Craduate a robust platform.

Settling in a country where one doesn’t belong is no mean feat and more often than not, the problems faced are logistics issues. At Craduate, we understand that a student should only be concentrating on his/her education and not worry about lodging, insurance, phone connection, money exchange, paperwork etc. So with its tie ups across US, Craduate will be able to make logistics as transparent and effortless for students as possible.

Craduate is not just a tool but a platform of mutual growth. Students, university representatives, alumni, and aspiring students, all have something to gain from this mutual association. We understand that gaining admission in a foreign university is not just a single event but a journey and Craduate can fuel that journey with enabling associations.

We hope to raise 10k by spring 2017 to facilitate tie ups with vendors, universities as well as city administration and lay the threshold of what we envision as the establishment of academic aspirations and creams.

If you are hard up to contribute but found this story phenomenal, here is what you can do.

Help Us Spread the word out and strengthen this campaign by sharing some Social love.

https://www.facebook.com/craduate

https://twitter.com/craduate

https://www.linkedin.com/company/craduate

Empower education, empower dreams! At craduate, we curate dreams into reality.

http://craduate.com

story:
Speranza Human Compassion Project. Learning that Changes YOU.

For women and children suffering in silence from violence and abuse in their home, it is a slow, quiet, suffocation of their potential to be happy and healthy. 

I, Christina Blackburn, Founder and Executive Director at Speranza Human Compassion Project, lived this way for many years until I was badly injured and then experienced first hand the gross marginalization of women and children that happens within healthcare and in human service agencies funded to be a part of the solution.

We began our research on the causes and of the extent of this major population health crisis in 2012 and found it to be an overwhelming problem in all health care, domestic violence shelters, at the court level, and in human & civil service agencies.

365 days a year in Philadelphia alone, 400 calls are made to 9-1-1 by abused women and children screaming for help from a violent person in their home. 400 calls means; 400 police, EMT, Physicians, Nurses, Shelter workers.. requiring to help. These are just the reported cases. Most cases are NOT reported to 9-1-1.

Through our research we discovered that each of these touchpoints receive NO effective intervention training on how to BEST respond appropriately to IP/DV yet, they will provide services every day.  This is a major cause of recidivism in this crisis.

The cycle

#1 Victim is beaten up

      Children witness (41% of cases)

#2  Victim reaches out for help

#3  Providers don’t know how to help and further injures the victim’s emotional trauma

#4  Victim return to abuser and feels that the systems put in place to help, let her down

#5 Beaten up


#6 DOES NOT CALL FOR HELP, SINCE HELP IS NOT PRESENT

#7 Victim stays in this cycle for lack of knowledge

The solution

#1 Victim is beaten up

      Children witness (41% of cases)

#2  Victim reaches out for help

#3  All providers (9-1-1 call responder, police, doctor, nurses, social worker, shelter workers) give solutions and compassionate care (typically a victim will require 3-6 providers)

#4 Victim may or may not return to abuser now that she knows what to do, but if she does..

#5 Victim sees the potential for further abuse

#6 Victim has a plan, knows what to do and makes safety a priority for herself and her children

For me, it was with God's help and my roommate in the shelter, that my life was saved. The fate of a women crying out for help, should not be left in the hands of a stranger. Without this stranger, I believe I would not be alive today.

With contributions of many people donating $1-5 or more (if you choose), we will be able to educate the next generation of leaders in healthcare on true, practical ways for them to be engaged in the solution so they can:


  • Make better personal relationship choices now and in their future families

  • Advocate for the victims they will serve in their professions

  • Be a part of the solution in ending violence against women

  • Lead in educating individuals and groups on campus and at their future employment


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $16,350 which will go to support our research team, overhead costs of the program, technology costs, and costs for building a framework to scale (marketing, technology, national network of consultants etc.).

  • Survivor led initiative that has an innovative solution for an extremely underserved population of women and children.

  • For donations of $5+ you will be recognized on our social media platforms, our website and in our newsletter that goes out to over 500 executives regionally.

The Impact

  • The value we bring is our impact on the care of women from all walks of life that are reaching out for help.

  • We have been successful in reaching over 75 students a year, training them to be advocates for women and children in crisis.

  • Check out our video to see some of our research project team..

Risks & Challenges

The major challenges we face are:

  • Resistance to a new strategy to prevent violence against women

  • Innovation is not embraced in this space

  • Because the topic is taboo, health system are uncomfortable admitting there is a problem and they need help

  • Funders wanting years of proven research and results

We all volunteer our time after working full-time jobs because this is our passion project. What we believe in and will make a change for women and children in crisis. Whether we are funded or not, we provide the needed training. It would help to be able to provide compensation for my team and the good work they are doing.

Because our project is based off of my real life experience, that has impact and is our unfair advantage over our competition, along with our completely new approach. 

Other Ways You Can Help


  • Partner with us on our mission to empower everyone who may touch a victim. Get your organization, university or hospital trained!

  • Volunteer with us as a counselor, contact us directly for details. We love our volunteers! <3

  • LIKE US on Facebook and Twitter and ask all of your friends to LIKE US!  #priceless

  • Help promote our Indiegogo campaign to your friends and family. Especially, if any of them are physicians, nurses, police officers, EMT, and managers/directors at a health system etc. Com'mon.. You gotta have at least one of these on one of your social media outlets.

  • Know that EVERY little bit helps.. If you get 5+ friends in the above professions or going into those professions, to like us, we WILL list you as a friend of the project!  Because that’s what you are.
story_txt:
Speranza Human Compassion Project. Learning that Changes YOU.For women and children suffering in silence from violence and abuse in their home, it is a slow, quiet, suffocation of their potential to be happy and healthy. I, Christina Blackburn, Founder and Executive Director at Speranza Human Compassion Project, lived this way for many years until I was badly injured and then experienced first hand the gross marginalization of women and children that happens within healthcare and in human service agencies funded to be a part of the solution.We began our research on the causes and of the extent of this major population health crisis in 2012 and found it to be an overwhelming problem in all health care, domestic violence shelters, at the court level, and in human & civil service agencies.365 days a year in Philadelphia alone, 400 calls are made to 9-1-1 by abused women and children screaming for help from a violent person in their home. 400 calls means; 400 police, EMT, Physicians, Nurses, Shelter workers.. requiring to help. These are just the reported cases. Most cases are NOT reported to 9-1-1.Through our research we discovered that each of these touchpoints receive NO effective intervention training on how to BEST respond appropriately to IP/DV yet, they will provide services every day.  This is a major cause of recidivism in this crisis.The cycle#1 Victim is beaten up      Children witness (41% of cases)#2  Victim reaches out for help#3  Providers don’t know how to help and further injures the victim’s emotional trauma#4  Victim return to abuser and feels that the systems put in place to help, let her down#5 Beaten up#6 DOES NOT CALL FOR HELP, SINCE HELP IS NOT PRESENT
#7 Victim stays in this cycle for lack of knowledge

#1 Victim is beaten up

story:
About the Writers' Room

THE CHILDREN: Literacy is important for our children. With the effect of social media, children rarely find the fun in picking up a book to read to better their reading skills. In the Writers' Room, children ages 8 and up are able to come up with their own story idea, and with the mentoring of Writers' Room staff, they will help each child develop their own story, help them with the critical thinking, guide them through researching their idea, and help them develop the story to eventually turn into a book. 

The beauty of this creative learning is that the children will have ownership of this project and they will want to read more as they continue to write more. The children will have access to computers, resource materials, Award winning Authors, and the design center where we will house designing programs like Photoshop where they can illustrate their own characters. 

As the children continue to frequent The Writers' Room, they will eventually complete their book and with the assistance of staff, they will have a physical book in hand to show their completion, becoming a "Tiny Author".

THE ADULTS: If you ever thought to yourself, "I want to write a book but I don't know how." The Writers' Room is for you too! When I became an author, I didn't know the first steps on how to do anything. I just knew I had an idea that I needed to get on paper and the rest I had to figure out on my own. With The Writers' Room, look no more, we've got you covered! Our staff will guide you through the entire process from helping you with your story idea, to help develop your story, to helping with your chapter layout, etc. 

All the resources that the children has, you will have that as well. Access to the printing stations, computers, and design labs, you will walk out of The Writers' Room with a completed novel, picture book, magazine, or even a cook book. Anything that needs to be designed, you will have access to the resources and equipment to become the author you have dreamed of.

What We Need & What You Get

I hear all the time, "I want to write my own book but I don't have the resources, the equipment, or thinking space to do this. When I'm at home, I'm bothered by my family where I can't think." 

OR 

"My little brother keeps knocking at my door annoying me, I can't think!" 

The Writers' Room will solve all the problems so we will need the following:

  • Computers, Computers, COMPUTERS! Without computers, the patrons won't have access to the internet for research, and they will not have a platform to type up their stories.
  • Printers/ Xerox. Once the book has been completed, you need a few pair of eyes to read over the story and edit it. Printers are key to this!
  • Computer Software. Writing is one thing but without artwork, you just have words on a page.
  • Supplies. Paper, Pens, Pencils, Notepads, Sticky notes, cleaning supplies, toiletries for the restroom, 
  • Furniture (Tables, Stools, Chairs). It's fun to sit on a ground but if you're as creative as I am, I'm all over the place while writing. I'm on the floor, laying on the sofa, sitting at a desk, or relaxing on a bean bag to get into my creative zone.
  • Television. What's a reception area without a TV?
  • Security System. It's probably a good idea to protect the equipment.
What Happens if I don't reach my goal?
  • Simple. The Writers' Room will still be open. Although we may not have everything we need to service the community, I strongly believe in "if you build it, it will come." 

The Impact

There are things in life that WE want to do as humans, then there are things in life that you are lead to do... This is called your purpose. 

My purpose is to make a huge impact in my community by making reading and writing fun again. 

The Writers' Room was birthed from "Tiny Authors Writers Workshop" and what I found while administering the workshops is that this was only a beginning. The kids were excited that they had the opportunity to create and write their own book, but at the conclusion of the workshop, they didn't know what else to do. I gave them an amazing start but what I struggled with later was being able to follow up with the kids to continue mentoring them to finish their book. I didn't have the resources or location to be able to mentor the children one on one and keep them motivated. However, with The Writers' Room, it will give them everything they need.

The children wants this, The children needs this, and I believe that my newfound purpose is to share my gifts with everyone and help push theirs.

In addition to the children, parents have attended the workshops with their children and asked for guidance on writing their own books. These are educators, stay at home mothers, community leaders, and small business owners. They all have information they want to get out there and with The Writers' Room, I'm able to activate their dreams.

Risks & Challenges

Opening up a Writers' Room will be challenging but my team and I have been preparing for these hurdles for the past year. We've researched the best location, the best technicians for the computers & equipment, and the best staff to be able to guide everyone who enters The Writers' Room. 

I don't have much so how can I Contribute?

Monetary is one thing that's needed but support and resources is another. There's many ways you can contribute besides monetary:

  • Donate anything: Computer paper, Writing utensils, books for resources, decorations, cleaning supplies, software CDs, printers, computers, furniture, etc. Anythings you can think of DONATE!!!!
  • SHARE: You may not have much to give but your friends, families, or coworkers might. Please share this page to bring The Writers' Room to the community of Bakersfield, CA.
  • PRAYERS: It's free and we can use it!
If you have any questions regarding donations, please feel free to email us at: sunnywillmedia@gmail.com
Thanks again for your support! 

- The Writers' Room

story:
Thank you for all the support! Our Indiegogo campaign has ended but we are still fundraising HERE!

We bought land! It's time to build our women's center!

Tiwale, which means "let us shine/glow" in Chichewa, was set up as a youth-led community based organization to empower Malawian women by providing economic opportunities through leadership workshops, micro-finance loans, vocational skills training, and education grants. To grow our efforts at providing economic opportunities for Malawian women, Tiwale has acquired a plot of land to construct an education center. This center will provide secondary school education classes and further vocational skills training for the women of Ntsiriza Community, Malawi

Our goal is to construct a space for education and entrepreneurship for women in Malawi. In the past, we have given school grants for women to return to school, however, two challenges were reported:

Challenge 1: The schools were located in faraway communities and so participants could not afford or spare the time for the commute.

Challenge 2: Their classmates in the schools were younger children which was embarrassing and discouraging.


The education center will be a safe growing space for women of all ages who were forced to leave school early due to varied circumstances. 

Tiwale will hire teachers to provide daily evening classes at a feasible time for a majority of the women in Ntsiriza Community. 

The classes will vary ranging from the sciences, humanities, languages and the arts to aid the women of Ntsiriza community in attaining the Malawi Secondary Certificate of Education (MSCE).


September 2015:

Purchased a plot for the construction of education center

September 2015:

Cost calculations and team building

March-May 2016:

Fundraising and sells of vocational skills training products

June 2016:

Commence construction of our education center

October-November 2016:

Curriculum buildings, project planning finalizing library and computer lab.

January 2017:

Launch classes!!



This is a break down for the budget for the full completion of the center, which includes a classroom, refuge home, an office space, community store, and operations for our first two years will total up to around US$20,000.


This is the floor plan for the future education center! We are really excited to see it get built this summer and for the future women who will get to utilize this center. 



Malawi is the world’s poorest country by per capita GDP. According to the International Fund for Agricultural Development, 74% of the Malawian population lives below the income poverty line of US$1.25 a day.

Most families cannot afford to finance their children’s education which can cost up to 30$ or more annually. Only 33% of the total amount of secondary aged students who should be enrolled in secondary school education is attending school. From this 33%, only 42% are girls. Most girls marry early in exchange for dowry; payment from the husband’s family.

With the infrequency of social mobility in Malawi, daughters and her daughter’s daughter often face the same fate: early marriage and insufficient schooling. Over time this vicious cycle has created a substantial population of women who are under-educated, jobless and facing extreme poverty.



To date, Tiwale has grown to training over 150 women in the business education programs, guiding 40 women to start businesses via micro-loans and another 30 women undergoing a vocational skills training program. 

The goal has been to promote the education of women and so with selling of fabrics made in the training program, Tiwale secured US$2,500 to purchase a plot of land to build an education center. 

With this space, we will provide secondary school education classes and further vocational skills development for the women in Ntsiriza community.




The Tiwale Team

Tiwale is youth-led community based organization. Our team members volunteer their services. We are all driven by a strong thirst to realize our vision of an innovative, empowered generation of Malawian women.


In partnership with the Integrated Development Group

The Integrated Development Group (IDG) is a student-driven, management consulting group sponsored by the University of the Pacific in Stockton, California. Founded in 2010, IDG seeks to accelerate high-impact social entrepreneurs and enterprises through an interdisciplinary approach to problem solving. 
IDG is comprised of a skilled team of undergraduate students who provide assistance to organizations through the completion of management consulting services.

This is the team that is working personally with the Tiwale organization to help make this a successful campaign and looks forward to seeing the launch of this education center. 

In partnership with Olympia's Art Collective

Olympia’s mission is to advance the women’s position in contemporary art as well as the entirety of art history. We act as a web, connecting female artists to one-another in order to break the gender binary that has remained present in art history to this day. More importantly, Olympia provides a lived sense of community. We hope to instill confidence and ambition within participants and guest alike.












'

1. SHOP and support by purchasing fabrics made in our vocational skills training program via our online store!

2. ORGANIZE a donation. We still need computers, lab equipment, first aid kits, books, art supplies and school supplies such as bags, stationary and boards.

3. VOLUNTEER and teach a vocational skill

4. SPONSOR the salary of a teacher

5. PROPOSE a curriculum

6. JOIN our team and board

7. SPREAD the word about our fundraiser

More importantly, Olympia provides a lived sense of community. We hope to instill confidence and ambition within participants and guest alike.





















'



1. SHOP and support by purchasing fabrics made in our vocational skills training program via our online store!
2. ORGANIZE a donation. We still need computers, lab equipment, first aid kits, books, art supplies and school supplies such as bags, stationary and boards.
3. VOLUNTEER and teach a vocational skill
4. SPONSOR the salary of a teacher
5. PROPOSE a curriculum
6. JOIN our team and board
7. SPREAD the word about our fundraiser

story:
À propos de moi..

  • Je m'appelle Guy-Serge Luboya, congolais d'origine, j'ai cependant passé mon enfance au Gabon où mes parents y travaillaient avant de déménager à Montréal au début des années 90.


  • Tous ces voyages au milieu d'autres cultures ont forgés en moi une ouverture d'esprit assez prononcée. Le hasard a voulu que je maitrise davatange la culture des autres avant la mienne.


  • Ainsi, j'ai eu quelques notions de Punu en grandissant avec les Bapunu dans la petite ville de Mouila (sud du Gabon). J'ai bien entendu appris le joual  et l'anglais à mon arrivé au Québec. J'ai aussi appréhendé le créole haitien dans la cours de mon école primaire à Montréal-Nord avec des amis d'Haiti. Je n'ai finalement appris le lingala (langue dominante dans mon pays d'origine) que des années plus tard.


  • Les langues ont donc toujours gravitées autour de moi, sans vraiment que je me pose trop de questions à leurs sujets.


Qu'est-ce qu'est ELA JAMBO ?

  • ELA est l'acronyme d'école de langue africaine, jambo signifie ''bonjour'' en swahili. L'école est la pionnière et unique en enseignement des langues africaines au Canada, ouvert en septembre 2012, l'établissement offre la posibilité à toute personne d'apprendre les langues d'Afrique, pour favoriser la communication interculturelle. L'école est née pour répondre au besoin de tout individu manifestant le désir d'assimiler une langue africaine.


  • ELA JAMBO a pour mission de changer le monde grâce au multilinguisme. En effet, en tant qu'être humain nous avons intérêt à protéger notre diversité. Cette dernière est menacée par la disparation quotidienne de plusieurs langues, et surtout africaines, emportant avec elles leur conception unique de l'univers.   


  • En contribuant à ce projet, vous luttez contre la pensée unique, contre la mentalité unilingue. Aussi, vous êtes un pionnier car vous contribuez à l'histoire du Canada. À l'élaboration de sa toute première école de langue africaine, au rapprochement entre les différentes cultures et communautés.


 Les langues africaines que nous offrons

  • Swahili
  • Wolof
  • Ciluba (Tshiluba)
  • Bambara
  • Lingala
  • Bassa
  • Kikongo


 Ce dont nous avons besoin

  Nous cherchons à récolter un montant de 10 000$. Avec cette somme, nous     serons en mesure de réaliser les opérations que nous caressons. Ces opérations  sont réparties en 3 objectifs principaux ; 

 1. Agrandissement des locaux pour avoir davantage de salles de classes et ainsi pouvoir proposer plus de langues.  

  2.  Lancer un nouveau programme pour enfants

  3. Proposer des cours en ligne


Au cas où nous n'obtenons pas la somme recherchée, nos options en ordre prioritaire vont comme suit ;

1. Agrandissement des locaux

2. Lancer un programme pour enfants

3. Proposer des cours en ligne


À quoi servira votre argent ?

L'argent récolté servira à :

  • La location de locaux afin d'offrir davantage de classes et de langues.
  • Monter de A à Z un nouveau programme destiné aux enfants.
  • La conception de ce programme pour enfants nécessitera l'achat d'outils pédagogiques, le recours au service d'un(e) linguiste spécialisé(e) dans l'enseignement à l'enfance.
  • L'achat d'une plateforme pour le service en ligne.


D'autres façons d'aider

  • Si vos moyens ne vous permettent pas de contribuer financièrement pour l'instant, vous pouvez relayer ce projet à vos proches et partager cette page sur les réseaux sociaux.
  • Bouche à oreilles : Parlez de ce projet à votre entourage au travail, à l'école, dans vos lieux de loisirs.
  •  Rappelez-leur d'utiliser les outils de partage Indiegogo !
story_txt:
À propos de moi..Je m'appelle Guy-Serge Luboya, congolais d'origine, j'ai cependant passé mon enfance au Gabon où mes parents y travaillaient avant de déménager à Montréal au début des années 90. Tous ces voyages au milieu d'autres cultures ont forgés en moi une ouverture d'esprit assez prononcée. Le hasard a voulu que je maitrise davatange la culture des autres avant la mienne. Ainsi, j'ai eu quelques notions de Punu en grandissant avec les Bapunu dans la petite ville de Mouila (sud du Gabon). J'ai bien entendu appris le joual  et l'anglais à mon arrivé au Québec. J'ai aussi appréhendé le créole haitien dans la cours de mon école primaire à Montréal-Nord avec des amis d'Haiti. Je n'ai finalement appris le lingala (langue dominante dans mon pays d'origine) que des années plus tard. Les langues ont donc toujours gravitées autour de moi, sans vraiment que je me pose trop de questions à leurs sujets. Qu'est-ce qu'est ELA JAMBO ? ELA est l'acronyme d'école de langue africaine, jambo signifie ''bonjour'' en swahili. L'école est la pionnière et unique en enseignement des langues africaines au Canada, ouvert en septembre 2012, l'établissement offre la posibilité à toute personne d'apprendre les langues d'Afrique, pour favoriser la communication interculturelle. L'école est née pour répondre au besoin de tout individu manifestant le désir d'assimiler une langue africaine.ELA JAMBO a pour mission de changer le monde grâce au multilinguisme. En effet, en tant qu'être humain nous avons intérêt à protéger notre diversité. Cette dernière est menacée par la disparation quotidienne de plusieurs langues, et surtout africaines, emportant avec elles leur conception unique de l'univers.   En contribuant à ce projet, vous luttez contre la pensée unique, contre la mentalité unilingue. Aussi, vous êtes un pionnier car vous contribuez à l'histoire du Canada. À l'élaboration de sa toute première école de langue africaine, au rapprochement entre les différentes cultures et communautés.  Les langues africaines que nous offrons 
Swahili
Wolof
Ciluba (Tshiluba)
Bambara 
Lingala
Bassa
Kikongo 
 Ce dont nous avons besoin 
  Nous cherchons à récolter un montant de 10 000$. Avec cette somme, nous     serons en mesure de réaliser les opérations que nous caressons. Ces opérations  sont réparties en 3 objectifs principaux ;  

 1. Agrandissement des locaux pour avoir davantage de salles de classes et ainsi pouvoir proposer plus de langues.  
  2.  Lancer un nouveau programme pour enfants 
  3. Proposer des cours en ligne 

Au cas où nous n'obtenons pas la somme recherchée, nos options en ordre prioritaire vont comme suit ; 
1. Agrandissement des locaux 
2. Lancer un programme pour enfants 
3. Proposer des cours en ligne 
À quoi servira votre argent ? L'argent récolté servira à : 
La location de locaux afin d'offrir davantage de classes et de langues.
Monter de A à Z un nouveau programme destiné aux enfants. 
La conception de ce programme pour enfants nécessitera l'achat d'outils pédagogiques, le recours au service d'un(e) linguiste spécialisé(e) dans l'enseignement à l'enfance. 
L'achat d'une plateforme pour le service en ligne. 


D'autres façons d'aider

Si vos moyens ne vous permettent pas de contribuer financièrement pour l'instant, vous pouvez relayer ce projet à vos proches et partager cette page sur les réseaux sociaux. 
Bouche à oreilles : Parlez de ce projet à votre entourage au travail, à l'école, dans vos lieux de loisirs. 
 Rappelez-leur d'utiliser les outils de partage Indiegogo !

story:
WAUW, IK BEN GESELECTEERD!!!
Het world championship of performing arts (wcopa) bestaat 20 jaar en special voor dit jubileum zijn oud kandidaten uitgenodigd om te strijden voor de titel. Ik ben trots en blij dat deze eer mij toekomt, het komt echter financieel op een ongelukkig moment.
Ik heb het vertrouwen gekregen van Roger Beleffi van het Missasubuhi record label and artist management die een deel van deze bijzondere mogelijkheid willen sponsoren.

Hun sponsoring en mijn allerlaatste spaargeld zijn helaas nog niet genoeg.

Help mij naar America waar ik deel kan nemen en misschien mijn gedroomde toekomst waar kan gaan maken.


Helpen doe je niet voor niets:

Iedere euro is welkom en verdient mijn warme dank.
om echter toch wat terug te kunnen doen verloot ik een aantal dingen.

onder iedereen die 10 euro of meer sponsored wordt een shoot verloot ter waarde van 175 euro.
verder verloot ik ook nog een makeup workshop, portret shoot en voor de geintreseerden een kindermakeup of kinderschmink partijtje.

iedereen die 150 euro of meer sponsored ontvangt een shoot bij Robbanna photography  inclusief visagie van mij. Alléén de eerste drie, dus wees er snel bij

onder de sponsors die gebruik maken van de fotoshoot wordt ook nog een videoshoot / promofilmpje verloot

Ik ben trots en blij dat deze eer mij toekomt, het komt echter financieel op een ongelukkig moment.Ik heb het vertrouwen gekregen van Roger Beleffi van het Missasubuhi record label and artist management die een deel van deze bijzondere mogelijkheid willen sponsoren.Hun sponsoring en mijn allerlaatste spaargeld zijn helaas nog niet genoeg.Help mij naar America waar ik deel kan nemen en misschien mijn gedroomde toekomst waar kan gaan maken.Helpen doe je niet voor niets:Iedere euro is welkom en verdient mijn warme dank.om echter toch wat terug te kunnen doen verloot ik een aantal dingen.onder iedereen die 10 euro of meer sponsored wordt een shoot verloot ter waarde van 175 euro.verder verloot ik ook nog een makeup workshop, portret shoot en voor de geintreseerden een kindermakeup of kinderschmink partijtje.iedereen die 150 euro of meer sponsored ontvangt een shoot bij Robbanna photography  inclusief visagie van mij.
