story:
My name is Eric “Fenix” Nelson. I currently live in Austin, Texas. I am an educator by trade, but also have always been an advocate and activist. I have taught at two tribally run schools, am an O.N.A.C. member, and stay involved in local Pow Wows and community efforts.

The Impact

On Oct. 27th militarized police and national guards cleared the Sacred Ground prayer camp that rested in the pathway of the pipeline construction. They interrupted sweat lodges and prayer circles, beating, pepper spraying, and throwing to the ground everyone present. If you are Catholic, imagine being pulled out of confessional, and being thrown to the ground and sat on. Or if you ascribe to another denomination of Christianity, yanked up from waiting to receive communion, to be beaten, and maced. This was what the peacefully praying people suffered for protecting their water supply, and praying for the sanctity of life that water provides. No amount of jobs is worth this. No amount of money from the sale of local oil is worth this. No amount of electricity or gas to drive cars is worth this!

Energy Transfer Partners, a corporation based in Dallas, in conjunction with Chervon, Sunoco and other investors is trying to hurry the completion of the Dakota Access Pipeline to begin pumping oil fracked from the Bakken fields in North Dakota to processing plants in Illinois, and Texas. Fracking creates toxic radioactive water in the process of extracting the last possible amount of oil from previously drilled reserves. This destabilizes the underground rock strata resulting in earthquakes, and the release of gasses.

This is being done under the premise of emminent domain, which allowed the government to run public utilities, like telephone, or electricity lines, across private property.  However the eventually processed fracked oil will also be shipped out and sold to foreign interests. That is hardly a public utility. It is vital for all of us and our posterity to keep this production from establishing itself. It is a ticking time bomb of environmental pollution across the largest watershed and river system in North America.

Winter will soon be upon the Oceti Sakowin and Sacred Stone Prayer camps and the rest of the water protectors standing with the Standing Rock Sioux. The water protectors have pledged to stay through the Winter, to continue to stop the poisoning of the largest watershed in North America. With that colder weather batteries can be less reliable, and their energy needs will increase as they'll daily need heat.

The media camp seems to have it’s power needs met now with the two solar panel trailers presented by Mark Ruffalo with the Solutions Project, and the original 20ft trailer of a 1.5kw solar unit powering the kitchen brought by Doug Yazzie and Brett Issac  renewable energy Project Manager for the Shonto Community Development Corporation in Navajo Nation. These trailers are now set up and have begun to produce electricity, but with 40,000+ people, more is still necessary. Instead of adding to the infrastructure of these arrays, the solar panels purchased here will be set up independently at the original prayer camp, and the school, which are still without electricity.

 

http://www.newamericanjournal.net/2016/10/winte...

http://m.bismarcktribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mark-ruffalo-each-time-they-hit-us-they-lose/article_379ee79b-7f9c-5bec-8d83-06d5995ce499.html

http://nativerenewables.com/

http://thesolutionsproject.org/

https://www.good.is/articles/the-solar-trailer-that-could-energy-innovation-inside-navajo-nation

The Sacred Stone Prayer camp was the first camp established last Spring on reservation land. It is where the elders, and leaders have met to conference, to conduct ceremony, and stand united in prayer. As numbers grew, Oceti Sakowin camp grew to house all the other First Nations to arrive, and additional supporters and allies. A school for the children has been running there. The Red Warrior Camp was established at the request of the original Camp of the Sacred Stones and was one of the first groups to utilized escalated direct action to stop the Dakota Access Pipeline. These solar panels will provide light and heat for these three groups.

 

There is a company in San Antonio called CoWatt Energy that manufactures an all-in-one free-standing solar panel ready to go with built in inverter. These units are stackable and easy to transport and set up.  They are made for on the ground solar-powered electricity production in rural applications. I can think of no better way to supply power to the prayer camp and school than clean solar power. This campaign is to purchase a sufficient number of units to send to the Sacred Stone Camp and their school.

What We Need & What You Get

We need the funds to purchase as many solar panel units as possible to sustain the camps and school through the harsh Winter months. Daylight is diminished during these times by clouds, and the more panels, the more electricity can be harvested. The goal here is to get an initial shipment out quickly before the first snow fall. The beauty of the Power Funnel is more units can quickly and easily be added on later. If the goal is not met or the order isn't enough for the camps needs, more can be sent later.

Fox Redsky will be traveling back to the camp for the third time, and will deliver and present the solar panels purchased from this campaign. They will be left there for the long haul and as a gift to the tribe.  

I will be in contact with Patrick Joel Pulliam, Lyla June, Kandi Mossett, and Dallas Goldtooth organizers with the Indigenous Environmental Network, LaDonna Allard and other camp members as well as department heads at the reservation office to help with installation and any problems that might arise with the arrays.

As a contributor you get the satisfaction of preserving pure drinking water for half of North America for your lifetime and posterity.

Many of you have been watching the #NoDAPL movement and are wondering how you can help. And what better way to help Mother Earth than getting off of fossil fuels and on to renewable energy.  A solar unit costs a lot of money to create and install, a typical house rooftop installation usually costs about $12,000. By comparison each PowerFunnel retails for $700. These portable light weight ground based PowerFunnels, can be moved and set up over and over, making them ideal for the camps.  

We thank you for your time and hope that you will be able to help bring solar Power to the People.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please share widely with friends, family, and organizations that might. 

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

In Solidarity,

Eric Fenix Nelson and Fox Redsky

MNI WICONI

#NoDAPL

Warriors on fire with righteous rage over the rape of the Mother of us all!

You Can't Drink Oil
Keep It In the Ground
story_txt:
My name is Eric “Fenix” Nelson. I currently live in Austin, Texas. I am an educator by trade, but also have always been an advocate and activist. I have taught at two tribally run schools, am an O.N.A.C. member, and stay involved in local Pow Wows and community efforts.
The Impact
On Oct. 27th militarized police and national guards cleared the Sacred Ground prayer camp that rested in the pathway of the pipeline construction. They interrupted sweat lodges and prayer circles, beating, pepper spraying, and throwing to the ground everyone present. If you are Catholic, imagine being pulled out of confessional, and being thrown to the ground and sat on. Or if you ascribe to another denomination of Christianity, yanked up from waiting to receive communion, to be beaten, and maced. This was what the peacefully praying people suffered for protecting their water supply, and praying for the sanctity of life that water provides. No amount of jobs is worth this. No amount of money from the sale of local oil is worth this. No amount of electricity or gas to drive cars is worth this!
Energy Transfer Partners, a corporation based in Dallas, in conjunction with Chervon, Sunoco and other investors is trying to hurry the completion of the Dakota Access Pipeline to begin pumping oil fracked from the Bakken fields in North Dakota to processing plants in Illinois, and Texas. Fracking creates toxic radioactive water in the process of extracting the last possible amount of oil from previously drilled reserves. This destabilizes the underground rock strata resulting in earthquakes, and the release of gasses.
This is being done under the premise of emminent domain, which allowed the government to run public utilities, like telephone, or electricity lines, across private property.  However the eventually processed fracked oil will also be shipped out and sold to foreign interests. That is hardly a public utility. It is vital for all of us and our posterity to keep this production from establishing itself. It is a ticking time bomb of environmental pollution across the largest watershed and river system in North America.
Winter will soon be upon the Oceti Sakowin and Sacred Stone Prayer camps and the rest of the water protectors standing with the Standing Rock Sioux. The water protectors have pledged to stay through the Winter, to continue to stop the poisoning of the largest watershed in North America. With that colder weather batteries can be less reliable, and their energy needs will increase as they'll daily need heat.
The media camp seems to have it’s power needs met now with the two solar panel trailers presented by Mark Ruffalo with the Solutions Project, and the original 20ft trailer of a 1.5kw solar unit powering the kitchen brought by Doug Yazzie and Brett Issac  renewable energy Project Manager for the Shonto Community Development Corporation in Navajo Nation. These trailers are now set up and have begun to produce electricity, but with 40,000+ people, more is still necessary. Instead of adding to the infrastructure of these arrays, the solar panels purchased here will be set up independently at the original prayer camp, and the school, which are still without electricity.
 
http://www.newamericanjournal.net/2016/10/winte...
http://m.bismarcktribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mark-ruffalo-each-time-they-hit-us-they-lose/article_379ee79b-7f9c-5bec-8d83-06d5995ce499.html
http://nativerenewables.com/
http://thesolutionsproject.org/
https://www.good.is/articles/the-solar-trailer-that-could-energy-innovation-inside-navajo-nation
The Sacred Stone Prayer camp was the first camp established last Spring on reservation land. It is where the elders, and leaders have met to conference, to conduct ceremony, and stand united in prayer. As numbers grew, Oceti Sakowin camp grew to house all the other First Nations to arrive, and additional supporters and allies. A school for the children has been running there. The Red Warrior Camp was established at the request of the original Camp of the Sacred Stones and was one of the first groups to utilized escalated direct action to stop the Dakota Access Pipeline. story:
How did it start?

Everything began with a crowd-sourced book project in 2010, when young Bosnian author Jasminko Halilović asked his peers "What did a war childhood mean to you?" After collecting more than 1000 short recollections (up to 160 characters) from more than 1000 people who were children during the war, he set out to edit them into a book. In 2013 Jasminko published “War Childhood” in the Bosnian language. Since then, the book has been translated into five more languages and further published in German and Japanese.

From book to museum

While working on his book, Halilović communicated with hundreds of participants. He noticed that besides feeling a need to share stories from their wartime childhoods, they also tended to connect their memories to physical objects. At the beginning of 2015 he assembled a team of anthropologists, historians, psychologists, and other contributors, which first developed a methodology and then began to put together a collection for the future War Childhood Museum. Fifteen months later, this collection now holds more than 3000 items and stories, as well as almost 100 hours of video testimonies.

In a country with staggering youth unemployment and an ongoing brain drain, the War Childhood Museum gives voice to the formative experiences of a generation marginalized by the country's post-war political economy. Just as importantly, it provides Bosnians of all ages a rare opportunity to confront the traumas of their recent past without reinforcing ethnic boundaries. Highlighting some of the pressing socio-cultural issues in contemporary Bosnia-Herzegovina, the War Childhood Museum also speaks to such broader topics as child development, social entrepreneurship, and historical memory in post-conflict societies.

What are we collecting?

The experience of growing up in war is complex. Our participants talk about it through various stories and objects. Here are some of them:

   

Mission and vision

The mission of the War Childhood Museum is to continuously and in accordance to the highest standards document and digitize materials related to growing up in the war, and to present the archived materials throughout various media channels in order to educate a broad audience about this experience.

The vision of the War Childhood Museum is to help individuals overcome past traumatic experiences and prevent traumatization of others, and at the same time advance mutual understanding at the collective level in order to enhance personal and social development.

Exhibition

Our first exhibition was held in May 2016. In ten days we drew over 4000 people. Visitors filled out two guest books with their comments and impressions, including the following:

"It’s wonderful to be part of this huge project. Thank you for restoring dignity and self-confidence to the young victims of war." (Sanja, participant)

"The exhibition was great. Only when I saw the exhibition did I realize that I should be grateful to have so much stuff. From this moment on I am grateful." (Omer, 8 years old)

Permanent exhibit

After months of struggle with local authorities we have finally secured a space for a permanent exhibit. It is located in the heart of Sarajevo and covers 263m2. We are going to renovate and equip the space to fit the needs of the exhibit.

Future Goals

After the initial internal research phase in Bosnia and Herzegovina, we will expand our research activities to other post-conflict zones. Our ten-year plan is to establish the world’s largest archive on the subject.  We will replicate our successful model in other countries by way of exhibitions and educational activities, thus broadening our impact. Aside from that, the War Childhood Museum hopes to become a globally-recognized voice for peace.

Support the opening of the War Childhood Museum by buying one of these:

Your lifetime passes will be waiting for you at the War Childhood Museum upon its opening.

As featured in

 

A 24-minute documentary about War Childhood Museum produced by Bosnian national broadcaster.

story:
Short Summary

 

  • Cuttington Campus School is a private primary and secondary school. It goes from nursery all the way to 12th Grade. The civil war  that took place over 13 years ago (1989-2003)  in Liberia took a huge toll on the school. Today you can still  see  remnants of the war, as the school struggles to get back to normalcy. The buildings look ruined, classrooms still remain damaged, windows and doors broken, damaged toilets and plumbing system, to name a few.  Yet students come regularly primped in their uniforms ready to learn. Despite all of the challenges, like the rain flooding the classrooms, termites eating the ceiling, no running toilets,  more and more students still come. Even our youngest learners and their teachers, in the kindergarten division of the school, are regularly in class despite all of these challenges. So, this year we decided to focus on the KG Division for this campaign because they are at the foundational level. This is where they start to form their understanding.  It is very bothersome to think that if the students get used to learning in the environment  such as it is now,  what message are they getting ?
  • By you  contributing to this renovation fundraiser, it will impact our students an teachers realise that their school environment does not have to be harsh for learning. It will send a message to the our first learners , the toddlers, to experience and see what is a normal learning classroom

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $ 10,000. 

Campus School's Kindergarten means a renovation transformation to make a conducive learning environment that is:

 Up to standards for learning with fixed windows, doors, ceilings, restrooms,  good chalk board that doesn't squeak

Well sanitized  with working flush toilets - no more smell of sewage

Chairs and desks that are suitable for the young learners height

Equipped with basic modern amenities like an air - condition for the hot weather

Equipped with  a  play  and reading area  to inspire learning 

The Impact

Students will get a beautiful classroom environment that is far different from what they have been used to. Students will enjoy the learning experience in a conducive environment. No more  smell of sewage in the classroom.  This will encourage learners to learn and not just trying to cope in a harsh environment. They will actually be able to  learn and play . Teachers will enjoy the art of teaching again with their students in a clean and beautiful atmosphere.  

We recently did a food-sale on the campus  for the KG division and all of the students , teachers and many parents  bought the food to support . Although not enough money was raised for the project, but the teachers were very much appreciative and happy that their building was getting some attention. In fact we started talking about getting things like curtains to cover the exposed windows.

  • This project is very valuable because it will really bring a change to the learning environment of our student.   Students and teachers have not enjoyed the pleasure of a kindergarten classroom.  The rooms are not conducive.  The windows are broken , smelling sewage where the toilet does not flush and bulky desk that are too high for their reach.

Risks  and Challenges

The challenge might be finding a good contractor within the area, committed to doing a good job in a timely manner and not delaying the work where it goes into instructional months.    There are contractors within the school campus area but the risk is that they may delay since they tend to work several other contracts at the same time.  Finding contractors from further away starts to get more costly. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools

story:
Qtime

Qtime is a creative place where we spend time wisely. That is why we decided to create a “space” that unifies a multitude of ways that help our members yield highest return on their investment of time. The project consists of three parts:

Qtime Anticafe is a kind of socially oriented public establishment where people pay primarily for the time they spend there. Anticafe is a common type of cafés which became really famous around the world, where people can get together with friends, have fun and meet new, interesting persons.

We decided to go further and added a possibility for all visitors to do events. Now our guests can attend education courses, master-classes organized by our partners, do yoga, have karaoke battles, watch movies on a wide screen.

 

 

Moreover, we have playing consoles with VR headsets for entertainment and developing needs, chess school and book sharing. Music room, which soon will become a recording studio, includes various treats, entertainments and projects that take place within our space. We value our time and our time has value. 

 

Qtime Coworking zone serves as a space where its’ users bring lives to their projects. Freelancers can work in the coworking zone, as well as individual employees of the big companies. It’s a place for people who don’t have a crew but are full of ideas and vice versa. As soon as we have positioned ourselves as an IT Hub, we have our own project, in which specialists can participate. This will provide them with new experiences and inspiration for starting something new on their own. We provide not only a place for young and ambitious people, but also give the opportunity to use powerful computers, software.

 Qtime FabLab is a fabrication lab where every visitor can come and take adventure of using the high-quality technical equipment which is: 3D printers, soldering stations, milling CNC machine, laser cutting, electronic tools, radio components. All these can be used without any limitations by each of our guests. Our staff aims to encourage everyone to get acquainted with the new tech and to inspire people to do something with their own hands. Master-classes and workshops, lectures and robotic construction are already implemented on the basis of FabLab.

 Our team 

Sergey is a founder of Qtime. Co-operation of young people, valuable spending of time and making new connections are the main Sergey’s goals. He is very hardworking person. Sergey knows for sure that there is nothing impossible – “All the problems we create by ourselves in our heads”.

story:
Story

We are a team of friends that are passioned about technology/software and we are always reading a lot of interesting articles around the web but we always encountered a problem by sharing those articles between us. We read articles from different sites, some of them not so known but with very good posts. We used a bunch of apps for finding articles and every time we said that it's difficult to share them between us. We had a Facebook group but we always were distracted by other notifications or messages and our focus from an useful information was taken away by some the personal ecosystem that Facebook offers.

One day we said, why don't we solve this problem by creating an app that will help us follow our articles from sites that we knew interesting and also had a common board (Sticky Board) where we just stick these bunch of articles and in this case no one won't miss a thing. We started this app and when we had and working prototype we started to be really engaged into it. Everyday searching for articles based on what hashtags we defined and in this way we were up to date with what happens in the technology field. Then we realised that if we had this problem, other teams have it so we transformed our app into grobyk.com. 

The name came up very quickly, we were one day at Starbucks and thinking about a cool name. First we started to enumerate the values that our app is based on and established that we want a team to grow by having the same knowledge base, so we came up with our slogan first: GRowing BY Knowing, then the name GROBYK.



Presentation


Three simple steps to make your team the best!

Register

It's simple to register. Name, email, password. You know the drill.


Add hashtags

Next. Add hashtags you like or just choose on trending ones.


Invite Members

Next. What’s a team without members? Invite all of them!


What does Grobyk offer for your team?


Introducing a new way to get informed: live articles flow

Everything is in your view.

Nothing is left behind.

75% more efficient algorithms.

Live feed from top sites.

Search with the help of hashtags.

All the top articles are here.

Discover new things, learn new stuff.


Introducing MBD Analytics:

The moment you start understanding your team is now.

Experience unique statistics for team management.

Increase your productivity.

Real time data structures based on hashtags.

Beautiful algorithms at your service.

Team general statistics to maintain workflow.

Personal AI Engine for exploring articles.

Look at those beautiful hashtags, they scatter the internet for you,

with the help of our AI Personal Engine.


We are applying to Indiegogo because we want to finish our mobile apps and Desktop apps also we want to increase our servers to give horsepower to the AI engine.
story_txt: StoryWe are a team of friends that are passioned about technology/software and we are always reading a lot of interesting articles around the web but we always encountered a problem by sharing those articles between us. We read articles from different sites, some of them not so known but with very good posts. We used a bunch of apps for finding articles and every time we said that it's difficult to share them between us. We had a Facebook group but we always were distracted by other notifications or messages and our focus from an useful information was taken away by some the personal ecosystem that Facebook offers.One day we said, why don't we solve this problem by creating an app that will help us follow our articles from sites that we knew interesting and also had a common board (Sticky Board) where we just stick these bunch of articles and in this case no one won't miss a thing. We started this app and when we had and working prototype we started to be really engaged into it. Everyday searching for articles based on what hashtags we defined and in this way we were up to date with what happens in the technology field. Then we realised that if we had this problem, other teams have it so we transformed our app into grobyk.com. The name came up very quickly, we were one day at Starbucks and thinking about a cool name. First we started to enumerate the values that our app is based on and established that we want a team to grow by having the same knowledge base, so we came up with our slogan first: GRowing BY Knowing, then the name GROBYK.PresentationThree simple steps to make your team the best!RegisterIt's simple to register. Name, email, password. You know the drill.Add hashtagsNext. Add hashtags you like or just choose on trending ones.Invite MembersNext. What’s a team without members? Invite all of them!What does Grobyk offer for your team?Introducing a new way to get informed: live articles flowEverything is in your view.Nothing is left behind.75% more efficient algorithms.Live feed from top sites.Search with the help of hashtags.All the top articles are here.Discover new things, learn new stuff.Introducing MBD Analytics:The moment you start understanding your team is now.Experience unique statistics for team management.Increase your productivity.Real time data structures based on hashtags.Beautiful algorithms at your service.Team general statistics to maintain workflow.Personal AI Engine for exploring articles.Look at those beautiful hashtags, they scatter the internet for you,with the help of our AI Personal Engine.We are applying to Indiegogo because we want to finish our mobile apps and Desktop apps also we want to increase our servers to give horsepower to the AI engine.

story:
Who, Why and How?

We are self-directed learners who are compelled to do meaningful work in our own community, despite the financial struggle that sometimes entails. Through our Summer 2014 Youth Leadership program, we were welcomed into The Whole Place at First Christian Church. We spent a year cleaning abandoned classrooms to transform trash into treasure in the Free Store, where over 500 members experience abundance. Now we have another neglected, unused space in the 90 year old church building in need of repairs to create a sanctuary for self-directed learners.
With your help, we can build a school more magical than Hogwarts, a home base from which our classroom opens up to include the surrounding wilderness preserve, parks, museums, and Uptown business district. Village Sudbury School will provide a much needed alternative for kids from Whittier and surrounding areas, where they can be free to play, free to learn, and free to discover themselves.
Details

We have an incredibly desirable location, but the space we are renting is badly in need of repair. Your support will allow us to:

  • Install a library, technology lab, and tool bench ($3000)
  • Replace loose, stained carpet with beautiful hardwood floors ($1000)
  • Rewire for safety and added outlets/lighting ($2000)
  • Obtain insurance, a business license, etc. ($2000)
  • Repair crumbling plaster walls ($500)
  • Produce signage and promotional materials, to market our school ($1000)
  • Build a reading cave and loft ($500)

Risks & Challenges

We are part of a very small but growing global movement for democratic education. There are currently around 30 Sudbury schools around the world. Dozens more have tried but failed. This won't be easy, and there are no guarantees, but we are confident we will succeed and determined not to quit until we do!

We have several strengths that set us apart from startups that didn't make it:

  • Existing relationship with our building owners, with partner projects such as the 500+ member Free Store and Academy of Music for the Blind on location
  • Walking distance to several parks, two museums, dozens of small businesses, City Hall, a public library, nature preserve, and Whittier College
  • While other startups opened with a dozen or fewer students, we are committed to opening with a minimum of two dozen, a critical mass that will help us grow to fifty or more students in the first three years
  • Experienced board of trustees -- 2 PhDs, a lawyer, fully credentialed teacher, leaders of Rotary International, and soon to be retired head children's librarian

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are struggling to make ends meet, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share this link with everyone you know, and help us canvass the community.
  • Come to one of our work days and contribute some sweat equity!

story:
Our Mission


Jimmy teaching at a school in Guam

Our mission is simple: to impact as many lives with our film as possible. 

We always knew that the early life of Jimmy Santiago Baca -- how his unlikely discovery of poetry while incarcerated in one of the worst US prisons transformed him from an illiterate, violent convict to a beloved, world-renowned writer -- was inspirational. Our feature-length documentary "A Place to Stand" has been called "a compelling look at the power of language" (Pasatiempo). Academy Award-winning Director Taylor Hackford ("Ray", "The Devil's Advocate") said it "presents Jimmy's story in the best way: by letting this great poet tell his own tale - and no one can tell a tale like Jimmy Santiago Baca." 

Our film has been seen by thousands in film festival screenings around the U.S., but our goal has always been more: to bring the film to schools, prisons, juvenile detention facilities and communities where this story can make the biggest impact. Jimmy's memoir remains very popular in prisons and in Los Angeles, it's the most stolen book from the Street Poets library. This is only part of what proves the hunger and need for this story. 

With your support, we will make the film and companion curriculum available for low-income communities and educational facilities nationwide. We know this film, Jimmy's story, can change lives. That's why we're fundraising. 


Our Educational Program


Jimmy giving a writing workshop at a school in Guam.

From the beginning, we wanted to do more than just produce and distribute our film -- we wanted to bring it to viewers on whom it could have a deep impact. So we designed curriculum and a student workbook. The idea is that the film can better reach its crucial audience -- teenagers, at-risk youth, and incarcerated individuals -- with a focused conversation surrounding its themes.

"Finding A Place to Stand", the film's curriculum, includes group discussions, activities, poetry prompts, and free-writes, and is centered on the concepts of individual power and strength. It has been piloted in nearly a dozen schools and has received much positive feedback from the teachers -- and the students! -- who have used it thus far.

You can view excerpts of the curriculum here: Finding A Place to Stand Curriculum Sample


Our Goals for 2016:

  • Over 50 public screenings across the US .

  • Release the film digitally and on DVD for consumers.

  • Partner with an educational distributor to maximize our reach to schools.

  • Secure broadcast distribution (TV presentation) for the film.

  • Provide the film, curriculum, and workbook materials to over 100 schools, prisons, and organizations.

  • Partner with prison reform organizations to use the film as an activism and awareness-raising tool.


Why Did We Choose Crowdfunding?


Our team at the world premiere of A Place to Stand in 2014. 

In this world of increasing negativity, we need stories like Jimmy's, more than ever, to serve as a counterbalance, to communicate that there is always hope and always possibility for positive change. Jimmy is a powerful role model for populations without many role models: incarcerated individuals, adolescents on the edge, and others impoverished and neglected by society. 

We know that we have something special on our hands, but without your support, the film won’t go very far. We don’t have a big distributor or a studio behind us. We don’t have big money. All we have is sweat and determination and passion. That’s why we’re crowdfunding - we need support to fund our grassroots distribution campaign. 

This project has been a people-powered effort from the very beginning and we want to continue that tradition until we achieve our goals. Without over a thousand people contributing from $1 to $20,000, we would have never completed the film. Because of that, we aren't beholden to investors or other interests - we can devote all of our resources into the communities we're aiming to serve. 


Our Story


Director Daniel Glick with Producer Gabriel Baca and Director of Photography Michael Gordon shooting "A Place to Stand".

In 2010, a 26-year-old Daniel Glick visited a friend's friend at Auburn Penitentiary. He was deeply struck by the intensity of the place and started cross-examining Tommy, who had been in prison for 15 years at that point, about life behind bars. The friend recommended Jimmy Santiago Baca’s memoir A Place to Stand. Daniel bought it, read it, and instantly knew he had to make a film about Jimmy’s experience.

Daniel moved to New Mexico in 2011, teamed up with Gabriel Baca (Jimmy's son) to form Catamount Films, and spent the next several years creating the film version of "A Place to Stand". Their intention was not only to shed light on the difficult experience of incarceration but -- most importantly -- to spread the message that it is possible to overcome even the most difficult circumstances.


The Trailer


The documentary itself details the childhood, conviction, and incarceration of Jimmy Santiago Baca, focusing intently on his transformation through literacy. 

Jimmy’s life shows us plainly that the power of literacy and self-expression to affirm life and enable us to make choices of healing, community, and service. In short -- it shows all of us who feel trapped that there is hope.


Budget Breakdown

  • $12,000: Outreach Team - This is the most important piece for our distribution efforts. This money will support our grassroots campaign of calls, meetings and emails, our word-of-mouth campaign to connect with the people, organizations and schools that will utilize the film and curriculum. 

  • $5,000: Physical Marketing Materials -  These are for the printing of DVDs, curriculum guides, workbooks and other physical marketing materials. 

  • $8,000: Administrative Support - This is to support personnel to organize screenings, ship materials, and work with schools and organizations to bring the film and curriculum to our target audiences. 

  • $5,000: Publicist - In order to get national press and dramatically increase the visibility and awareness of our film and educational campaign, we need to hire a publicist, someone who knows how to cut through the media bureaucracy and connect with press outlets that could share the story of our mission. 

This budget will support our educational campaign for 6 months. Every dollar raised will go directly towards the above effort.
All donations are tax-deductible via our 501(c)3 fiscal sponsor the Center of Southwest Culture. 
For more information about the film and our team, you can visit www.aplacetostandmovie.com. Thanks so much for supporting our efforts!

story:
Our project in 4 points

·  Two exciting fun and educational card games.

·  Familiarizes players with the human body.

·  Provides information on how to keep the human body healthy.

·  When we exceed our funding goal we will donate games to underprivileged youth programs (nonprofit organizations)

Impact

The fundamental idea is to familiarize players with the different organs of the human body and ways of keeping the human body healthy. The Anatomy Connection card games editions 1 and 2 are beneficial to children because it gives them a foundation on how the body works, as well as ways to keep it healthy. The more children know about the human body the more likely they will make decisions that are healthy for them.

Who are we?

We’re just two creative parents who enjoyed playing card games as children. The human body has always fascinated me, so one day while researching information about the human body it dawned on me, kids/people would love to have a fun way to learn about the human body. So my wife and I began developing the games, we wanted to teach children about the human body in a fun way so my wife decided to color coordinate the different systems of the body. I wanted to spice things up with “wild” cards and “action” cards, so I added some organ donor cards and bypass cards to the games. The games are played by simply matching up the color coordinated cards to receive an organ for that system. The first person to complete their body board wins the game. This teaches children what organs go in which systems of the human body. We also had help from my good friend Dr. Arthur Wolf who was able to add facts to the cards.  The graphics took some time to develop, but with the help of my artistic wife and a graphic design artist (Brian Duddles) our vision for Anatomy Connection was brought to life.

What we need and what you get

To launch the project, we need funding for the printing; the body boards, the die-cut chipboard pieces and the boxes.  The bigger the order, the less it costs per game, so we’d like to order at least 2500 of each edition of the games, which is what the money collected from the Indiegogo campaign will go towards.

Perks

·  For $20 receive one copy of Anatomy Connection card game edition, you will be able to specify which edition you want.

·  For $30 receive both editions of the Anatomy Connection card games, edition 1 provides facts about human organs. Edition 2 provides facts on keeping the systems of the human body healthy.

·  For $25 receive a special (Limited “Indiegogo” edition) of the Anatomy Connection card game you will be able to specify which edition you want.

·  For $50 receive a special (2 pack) of the limited “Indiegogo” Anatomy Connection card games edition 1 and 2+ our everlasting thanks for supporting our project.

Other Ways to Help

Word of mouth has been identified as the most valuable form of marketing so with your help by sharing our indiegogo campaign with your social media, telling your friends and family, and the schools your children attend about Anatomy Connection would be greatly appreciated.

Risks and Challenges

We plan on driving to Pahrump, Nevada to the print company “Board Game Manufacturing Company” to pick up the initial shipment; our only challenge will be delays that are beyond our control.

story:
How would the world be different if every change effort had a network map of the people working toward that change?

The fundamental tool for learning about, developing, strengthening and leveraging human networks is a network map. A map that reveals the kinds of relationships people have to one another, the kinds of interests they share with one another, what they can offer to and need from one another, and what would motivate them to contribute to the network.

A map that helps the system see itself. A map that stimulates the collective imagination about what it means to be a network, and what a network makes possible.

How different would our lives be, if we could visualize, even if only in part, the immensity of what we ARE together?

Help us unleash the power of Network Mapping for complex systems change.

Greater than the Sum is committed to supporting the shift from systems of dominance to systems of connection by increasing access to network mapping for all social justice & social change efforts, regardless of their budgets or technical skills.

 

 

Network maps help create & leverage catalytic & resilient social change networks. They help a network 'see itself', representing the whole while providing detailed info about the parts and the flows. 

And there are some wonderful NEW online interactive mapping platforms available (Kumui.io is our favorite).

But until now, gathering meaningful relationship data from network members has been messy, time-consuming, and required data-wrangling skills most people don't have and shouldn't need to have. 

sumApp changes all that!

We spent the past year and a half developing sumApp, an online tool that makes the data-gathering  step as easy as to administer as using SurveyMonkey, and as easy for community members to use as following folks on Twitter. 

Even better, sumApp exports data in a network-friendly format that can instantly be imported into platforms like Kumu (our fave), Polinode, Gephi and others (which is precisely what you don't get from other survey platforms).  With sumApp, one needn't be a spreadsheet wizard to use those fabulous mapping tools.

 

 

Phases I & II are completed

Phases I & II were all about getting the basic functionality in place, testing it with clients (it works great!), and making the basic features available to the public online, for a very low price. And we've done that. (Yayy!!)

Phases I & II were entirely self-funded – we invested our own time and our own money to hire the developers - because we feel so strongly about this critical tool.

But our pockets are not deep, and we’re tapped out! Launching Phase II is super exciting, but it's a loss-leader, a nearly-free introductory part of the cost structure - so even if it’s an instant wild success, it won’t stop the financial drain.

 

 

We need help getting to Phase III

We need a quick, $6,000 cash infusion to get through to Phase III, when the project can become financially sustainable.

In Phase III, we will:

  • Develop the bells & whistles that professional mappers (like us) need. These features will give our clients the customization they want, and make mappers jobs even easier (so they can make more maps!)
  • Develop Network Mapping learning curriculum to help increase capacity in addition to offering tools.
  • Develop an online community for learning everything there is to know about network mapping – a network of network mappers.
  • Continue to research & prototype ways for network mapping to facilitate systems change.
  • Continue to enhance the tools based on those experiments. 

That’s the vision - Phases I & II solved the biggest technical barriers and Phase III ensures the solution remains available,  spreads capacity, and promotes the network mapping paradigm.

We want to ensure that the basics of sumApp are always affordable - but without the immediate financial push to help us roll out those extra bells & whistles, we won't be able to keep it going.

As you contribute, our developers will turn your money directly into sumApp improvements, and we'll keep you informed about those improvements in real time. 

Be part of making network maps as accessible & useful as spreadsheets!

More Ways You Can Help

If you can't pitch in money, but want to support us, here are some ways you could help us get the word out and make some noise about campaign:

  • Follow us on Twitter
  • Share this campaign on Social Media
    • Use the share buttons next to the 'Back It' button
    • Email it using this short link: https://igg.me/at/sumapp
    • Say something about our campaign your social impact groups in FaceBook
  • Tell people who might be interested about sumApp
    • Share the link to the sumApp landing page  www.greaterthanthesum.com/sumapp
    • Tweet about us
    • Post us on FaceBook - especially in your social change groups
  • Like our videos on YouTube -  sumApp YouTube Channel - that will help sumApp get found by the search engines!

sumApp changes all that!
We spent the past year and a half developing sumApp, an online tool that makes the data-gathering  step as easy as to administer as using SurveyMonkey, and as easy for community members to use as following folks on Twitter. 
Even better, sumApp exports data in a network-friendly format that can instantly be imported into platforms like Kumu (our fave), Polinode, Gephi and others (which is precisely what you don't get from other survey platforms).  With sumApp, one needn't be a spreadsheet wizard to use those fabulous mapping tools.
 

 
Phases I & II are completed
Phases I & II were all about getting the basic functionality in place, testing it with clients (it works great!), and making the basic features available to the public online, for a very low price. And we've done that. (Yayy!!)
Phases I & II were entirely self-funded – we invested our own time and our own money to hire the developers - because we feel so strongly about this critical tool.
But our pockets are not deep, and we’re tapped out! Launching Phase II is super exciting, but it's a loss-leader, a nearly-free introductory part of the cost structure - so even if it’s an instant wild success, it won’t stop the financial drain.
 

 
We need help getting to Phase III
We need a quick, $6,000 cash infusion to get through to Phase III, when the project can become financially sustainable.
In Phase III, we will:

Develop the bells & whistles that professional mappers (like us) need. These features will give our clients the customization they want, and make mappers jobs even easier (so they can make more maps!)
Develop Network Mapping learning curriculum to help increase capacity in addition to offering tools.
Develop an online community for learning everything there is to know about network mapping – a network of network mappers.
Continue to research & prototype ways for network mapping to facilitate systems change.
Continue to enhance the tools based on those experiments. 

That’s the vision - Phases I & II solved the biggest technical barriers and Phase III ensures the solution remains available,  spreads capacity, and promotes the network mapping paradigm.
We want to ensure that the basics of sumApp are always affordable - but without the immediate financial push to help us roll out those extra bells & whistles, we won't be able to keep it going.
As you contribute, our developers will turn your money directly into sumApp improvements, and we'll keep you informed about those improvements in real time. 
Be part of making network maps as accessible & useful as spreadsheets!
More Ways You Can Help

If you can't pitch in money, but want to support us, here are some ways you could help us get the word out and make some noise about campaign:


Follow us on Twitter


Share this campaign on Social Media
Use the share buttons next to the 'Back It' button
Email it using this short link: https://igg.me/at/sumapp

Say something about our campaign your social impact groups in FaceBook



Tell people who might be interested about sumApp
Share the link to the sumApp landing page  www.greaterthanthesum.com/sumapp

Tweet about us
Post us on FaceBook - especially in your social change groups



Like our videos on YouTube -  sumApp YouTube Channel - that will help sumApp get found by the search engines!

story:
Short Summary

Life-Changers and Game-Changers. Radicals and Revolutionaries. Risk takers and Adventurers. Creatives and Thinkers. 

These are the people that will shape the future- and the way is through education. Authentic, quality education. Right from the very start.  

Education is the way to radically impact the future and change the face of whole societies. It's the proven and sustainable way of lifting people out of poverty.

“Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world,”  Nelson Mandela

Short history

"We still remember the overwhelming joy that exploded among us, when it was announced that we have been given 7.5 hectares of  land.

Now, 8 years later, Global Challenge Leadership Campus is a platform and launching pad to the future leaders of South Africa. We have built 2 schools on the campus, (Global Leadership Academy and Oakridge Academy) together with resident houses (for students that come from far) and a memorial house (for our volunteers). And we need your help to further the building project. We can not do it without you..."

Global Challenge is registered with the South African Department of Social Development since 2009 as a Non Profit Organization, with registration number: 066-651-NPO. The architect, engineers and other experts working on this project have offered their services on a volunteer basis. This is an encouraging sign proving that this venture is worth the sacrifice and investment from you.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We have two schools with close to 400 children- and more are coming next year.
  • To meet the need we are adding 4 CLASSROOMS with an estimated cost of $4500 per classroom. 
  • You invest. We educate.
  • You don't have to do any of the work. Your contribution will harvest a great reward.

The Impact

Our province (Eastern Cape) has the lowest average pass rate in South Africa. Yet our high school, Global Leadership Academy, has consistently scored a 100% pass rate in our final school year- for the last 4 years! 

Your investment directly influences the child on the ground. Better facilities mean more students that can be directly influenced to become the leaders of the future.

Many of our students have gone on to study and work. Many who never had a realistic opportunity of doing so in the past.

No child should receive a watered-down education. We want to give the best to create the best.

Risks & Challenges

  • Next year's students are already enrolled - we are working around the clock to make the deadline of finishing our 4 new classrooms.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially you can help in other ways:

  • Tell a friend
  • Sign up as a volunteer

story:
Dear supporter:

The assault on public and higher education by the Trump administration has made first in the family funding even more urgent.  As the administration prepares to gut what remains of public K-12 education, schools around the nation will see lower college-going rates among their most vulnerable youth populations. With high rates of push-out and policing in Los Angeles schools, undocumented, foster care, homeless and LGBTQ students face even greater odds in their quest for college admission and graduation.  With your renewed support, we hope to award L.A. and national students of color another round of $1000 scholarships to assist with their books, tuition, housing and other living expenses.  Our 2013-2018 scholars are now at USC, UCLA, UC Riverside, Cal State University Long Beach, Babson College, University of North Texas, UC Merced, El Camino College, UC Berkeley, Amherst College, Cal State Dominguez, NYU, the University of Pennsylvania and Carleton College.  Listen to their stories and please circulate our campaign widely!  

Black Skeptics Los Angeles

Sydney Steward, University of Pennsylvania, 2017 scholarship winner

During my youth, I attended a church that often left me feeling empty inside. Sermons were boisterous, beautiful in the way that hymns captivated the broken souls sitting in the pews. Spirituals claiming to sew the pieces of a person back together put smiles on faces, brought tears to eyes, and moved people to rise on their feet. Reaching out with weary hands, they felt the ‘Holy Spirit’—but I didn’t. I sat and watched people pour their problems into a mysterious being. My mother always reminded me that the bible is simply a book of short stories. I could not fathom how adults lived according to folklore. The same god who claimed to love all his children hypocritically shunned those who did not align with his dicta. The same god who claimed to promote peace and love desecrated the lives of millions of people every day. Confusion and anger plagued my conscience. With every Sunday that passed, I realized a raw truth.

Blind trust is intoxicating.

When asked the question, “Do you believe in God?” I awkwardly reply, “I don’t know” or “I am trying to figure that out.” Rarely am I asked, “What do you believe in?” I was raised in a culture of binaries; either you subscribe to a religion or you repel any system of non-scientific belief. While I do dislike the cult-like, elitist nature of Christianity, I do not live without a moral compass. None of us do; the human propensity consists of the need to delineate good and evil. Why attach divisive religions to this natural phenomenon? Good and evil mingle inside each and every one of us. Virtue is not static; I love the liberation that comes with writing the rules as I go. My agnosticism is rooted in my introspective nature; I imbibe the world around me to produce thoughts and conclusions. My endless desire to pursue this world with a clear mind and open arms often streamlines the development of my social conscience. Around me, I see discrimination, pain, and suffering. Around me, I see souls striving to survive in a system designed to weed them out. Around me, I see an aching need for change. My religious freedom lends me the leeway to be that change. Although I will never know whether a higher being exists, I do know that the world exists; humans exist; most importantly, the power of individual choice exists. So, I make poignant choices every day to advocate for myself and those who are silenced. With empathy as my fuel and passion as my road map, I navigate life fiercely fighting for all that I think is right. What truly warms my soul—I get to define that. Not society, not a deity, not a century-old tome, and certainly not a little kid sitting across from me in art class. I am free. My morality isn’t based in blind trust; instead, my morality is simply, utterly, and beautifully, mine.

story:
utopía {portátil} • desde 2014


Somos una asociación civil y un sello editorial venezolano dedicado a la difusión
del imaginario latinoamericano y la realización de performances editoriales a partir
de la gráfica. Hacemos libros y desplegamos nuestras páginas en talleres y
experiencias de creación, dirigidos a comunidades cuyo acceso a los libros, la
literatura, la imagen y la palabra se encuentra limitado por dinámicas de exclusión
social así como por los alcances del mercado editorial.

Nuestros libros

Hasta ahora, hemos publicado cinco libros: dos dirigidos a niños de cualquier edad {Juano + El Espanto} y otros pensados para un público más adulto {Álbum para colorear mientras salimos del jardín} aunque los pequeños también los disfruten; también para el público general hay poesía {40 Consejos para un perro callejero} con y sin pulgas, {Bonnie Parker y la posibilidad de un árbol …el camino más espinoso}. Cada uno de ellos ha tenido su propia historia –con flores y espinas–, y en todos hemos querido que las tecnologías manuales de producción y reproducción de la imagen formen parte del proceso creativo. Tapas impresas en serigrafía, tipografía dibujada a mano, papel hecho en Venezuela, música especialmente compuesta para la ocasión… son algunas de las cosas que hacen a nuestros libros objetos realmente especiales. Porque nuestros autores, ilustradores, diseñadores, correctores, impresores, encuadernadores, son todos talentos locales, y nuestras ediciones son el resultado de una dura pelea por mantener y fortalecer el tejido que sostiene una industria cada vez más vulnerable en nuestro país.

Somos portátiles

Utopía {portátil} hace libros, pero nuestra principal motivación es llegar a las comunidades más alejadas de la industria editorial. Nos gustan los mecanismos artesanales de impresión, manuales, porque con ellos podemos llevar la imprenta a donde sea.

Dictamos talleres, llevamos imágenes que desencadenan nuevas historias y promueven la empatía narrativa, la comprensión visual, la escucha oral. Imprimimos juntos en las plazas para que nuestros cuentos se vuelvan sus historias. Nos juntamos, pintamos murales, jugamos con las palabras, hacemos imágenes, escuchamos su voz. Y queremos hacer más: llegar más lejos, más adentro y por más tiempo.

Recursos más que humanos

Utopía {portátil} es una asociación civil sin fines de lucro. Creemos en nuestro capital humano, en el valor del trabajo creativo. Nuestro equipo está lleno de talentos y buenos propósitos. Autores y colaboradores (ocasionales y permanentes) que intervienen en la producción editorial y son la utopía posible. Profesionales que hacen prodigios con los recursos que caen en sus manos. Apoyamos el talento local y promovemos el trabajo de nuestro héroes anónimos, esos que son capaces de trabajar aún en las circunstancias más adversas.

 

#QueremosSeguirRodando 
 

ZooOnomatopeyas:  ¡ ya casi, estamos a punto de imprimir !

Luis Cardozo Romero, textos
Coralia López, ilustraciones

Gracias a la facultad de imitar, podemos apropiarnos de la musicalidad de la naturaleza para comprenderla mediante gruñidos, graznidos, ladridos, cantos y trinos. ZooOnomatopeyas está diseñado como un conjunto de 32 tarjetas sueltas de 10 x 15 cm. Además de las 29 letras del alfabeto, incluimos los 2 dígrafos que fueron desincorporados del alfabeto en Castellano. Decidimos rescatarlos por el valor cultural que le damos al proceso de lecto-escritura que vivieron muchas generaciones… porque la utopía es también un poco Vintage.

P onemos este coroto en tus manos.
R uidos, sonidos, ABC de voces.
E stas onomatopeyas feroces.
S on, sí, de animales venezolanos,
E pa, y también latinoamericanos.
N a’guará: poesía brota como arroces
T rabalenguas con cuentos pa’que goces
Á lbum de ofrendas para esos zánganos.
N uestros pueblos indígenas conviven,
D ialogan con fauna: en un condominio.
O h, va, con ñapa de “Ch” y “Ll” en parejo.
L a bulla, el escándalo se desviven...
E a, guachafita: ¡calla en conticinio!
S obrinos de Tío Tigre y Tío Conejo.

¡ Si, a punto de caramelo !

Con los donativos que logremos recaudar, esperamos cubrir los procesos de
producción:

- Fotolito: imposición y planchas de impresión.
- Material para imprimir: sulfato laminado
- Imprenta
- Empaque de tela impreso en serigrafía
- Gastos operativos
- Adicionalmente, quisiéramos retribuir monetariamente el enorme esfuerzo de muchos colaboradores que han apostado por esta utopía.

Siempre puedes hacer algo

Aquellos que no puedan contribuir con donativos, también pueden darnos una mano: dile a tus amigos que compartan esta campaña, así seremos muchos más los que soñemos con ojos abiertos. Somos utopía {portátil} y #QueremosSeguirRodando

story:
Dear friends and supporters,

You might know me from my two previous campaigns 'Stephanie's Masai Education Fund' 1 + 2 with which I raised funds for our Masai community to receive training in land management and with which I distributed close to 300 reusable sanitary kits to the girl students and women of our community.

Should you not know me: Hi, I am Stephanie, married to a Masai warrior and resident of the village of Lesoit, Kiteto, Tanzania for 7 years, where I work for the conservation of Masai culture and the environment they live in.

With this campaign I would like to continue the work from my reusable sanitary kits project, with one major step towards sustainability: instead of buying the kits, I am now looking to teach the Masai women how to MAKE these kits. Teach them how to MAKE them and SELL them. Setting up a sustainable all woman enterprise which will empower them socially and economically and which will produce profits which will be used for the educational and environmental development of our community (and beyond).

There are three things we will need to start this enterprise and for which we are asking for your support:

1) We will need two manual sewing machines to get us started making kits

2) We will need sewing training specifically in making these kits.

3) We will need materials for making the kits.

 

The kits have a unique design with the patent belonging to a non-profit organisation which makes and distributes these kits worldwide: 'DAYS for GIRLS INTERNATIONAL' (https://www.daysforgirls.org) 

The kits I purchased with the help of generous donors in my previous campaign, were purchased here in Tanzania, from an NGO called 'UMOJA' (https://www.umojatanzania.org) which is a Days for Girls enterprise. 

We are in discussion with Umoja to have myself and two Masai ladies from Lesoit trained in making the kits according to the Days for Girls standard. This will involve us travelling to Arusha, where Umoja is based, and spend five days getting trained.

 

The funds we need to do this, are as follows:

Sewing machine ×2                                                                                           300$

                                                                             

Training for 3 people in Arusha                                           ~                        300$

Transport, accomodation & food                                       ~                         430$     

 

Materials for a start-up of 50 kits                                       ~                        290$

Certification with 'Days for Girls'                                                                     50$

 

Total                                                                                                     1370$ 

 

We believe education is the key to securing a more secure future and new skills learned will give the Masai women the confidence needed to change their lives for the better. We also believe that women are the changemakers in their communities and that their worldwide oppression is damaging to their communities.

This is why I have decided to climb Mount Kilimanjaro in March 2019 with an international all-women's group. The trek is organised by an Australian organisation called 'Wanderlust Women's Adventures' (http://www.wanderlustwomensadventures.com) who organise sustainable travel giving back to local communities and especially women by providing reusable sanitary kits, education and small business incentives. 

With this trek, we hope to raise awareness of women's plights and the threats indigenous communities face worldwide.

We appreciate your kindness and generosity and would like to reward you again with beautiful gifts in exchange for your donation.

We offer Masai blankets, earrings, bracelets and beautifully beaded Masai sandals which is a new perk we introduced for this campaign. We also offer you the unique opportunity to come and stay with us in our traditional Masai home. 

Should your generous contributions push us over our goal, we will use these to fund more material for more kits. 

 

This campaign does not fund a one-off improvement in the lives of the Masai. This campaign funds education and skills and capacity building which will last a lifetime. With this campaign, we guarantee a step towards sustainability to last for generations to come and which will ease the pressure the Masai face trying to sustain their traditional way of life. 

 

I have come to love my husband's tribe - each and everyone of them is family to me. There is nothing I wish for more than to see this beautiful tribe survive the onslaught of modernity which has befallen it. I believe the Masai’s culture to be just as worthy of preservation as Africa’s natural heritage like lions and elephants - and I try with all that I do to help them find a balance between tradition and modernity for the sake of their tribal identity.

So with this campaign, you are not only funding women empowerment and promoting gender equality. You are not only implementing sustainable development. You are helping safeguard our world's cultural heritage and one of our planet's last remaining indigenous tribes. 

 

Please consider supporting us and please do spread the word about this campaign. Talk to your friends and family and feel free to share away. Check out my previous campaigns and my social media accounts and please get in touch if you have any questions or suggestions.

I hope we can continue to work together to make this world a better place.

 

Thank you.
story_txt: Dear friends and supporters,You might know me from my two previous campaigns 'Stephanie's Masai Education Fund' 1 + 2 with which I raised funds for our Masai community to receive training in land management and with which I distributed close to 300 reusable sanitary kits to the girl students and women of our community.Should you not know me: Hi, I am Stephanie, married to a Masai warrior and resident of the village of Lesoit, Kiteto, Tanzania for 7 years, where I work for the conservation of Masai culture and the environment they live in.With this campaign I would like to continue the work from my reusable sanitary kits project, with one major step towards sustainability: instead of buying the kits, I am now looking to teach the Masai women how to MAKE these kits. Teach them how to MAKE them and SELL them. Setting up a sustainable all woman enterprise which will empower them socially and economically and which will produce profits which will be used for the educational and environmental development of our community (and beyond).There are three things we will need to start this enterprise and for which we are asking for your support:1) We will need two manual sewing machines to get us started making kits2) We will need sewing training specifically in making these kits.3) We will need materials for making the kits. The kits have a unique design with the patent belonging to a non-profit organisation which makes and distributes these kits worldwide: 'DAYS for GIRLS INTERNATIONAL' (https://www.daysforgirls.org) The kits I purchased with the help of generous donors in my previous campaign, were purchased here in Tanzania, from an NGO called 'UMOJA' (https://www.umojatanzania.org) which is a Days for Girls enterprise. We are in discussion with Umoja to have myself and two Masai ladies from Lesoit trained in making the kits according to the Days for Girls standard. This will involve us travelling to Arusha, where Umoja is based, and spend five days getting trained. The funds we need to do this, are as follows:Sewing machine ×2                                                                                           300$                                                                             Training for 3 people in Arusha                                           ~                        300$Transport, accomodation & food                                       ~                         430$      Materials for a start-up of 50 kits                                       ~                        290$Certification with 'Days for Girls'                                                                     50$ Total                                                                                                     1370$  We believe education is the key to securing a more secure future and new skills learned will give the Masai women the confidence needed to change their lives for the better. We also believe that women are the changemakers in their communities and that their worldwide oppression is damaging to their communities.This is why I have decided to climb Mount Kilimanjaro in March 2019 with an international all-women's group. The trek is organised by an Australian organisation called 'Wanderlust Women's Adventures' (http://www.wanderlustwomensadventures.com) who organise sustainable travel giving back to local communities and especially women by providing reusable sanitary kits, education and small business incentives. With this trek, we hope to raise awareness of women's plights and the threats indigenous communities face worldwide.We appreciate your kindness and generosity and would like to reward you again with beautiful gifts in exchange for your donation.We offer Masai blankets, earrings, bracelets and beautifully beaded Masai sandals which is a new perk we introduced for this campaign. We also offer you the unique opportunity to come and stay with us in our traditional Masai home. Should your generous contributions push us over our goal, we will use these to fund more material for more kits.  This campaign does not fund a one-off improvement in the lives of the Masai. This campaign funds education and skills and capacity building which will last a lifetime. With this campaign, we guarantee a step towards sustainability to last for generations to come and which will ease the pressure the Masai face trying to sustain their traditional way of life.  I have come to love my husband's tribe - each and everyone of them is family to me. There is nothing I wish for more than to see this beautiful tribe survive the onslaught of modernity which has befallen it. I believe the Masai’s culture to be just as worthy of preservation as Africa’s natural heritage like lions and elephants - and I try with all that I do to help them find a balance between tradition and modernity for the sake of their tribal identity.So with this campaign, you are not only funding women empowerment and promoting gender equality. You are not only implementing sustainable development. You are helping safeguard our world's cultural heritage and one of our planet's last remaining indigenous tribes.  Please consider supporting us and please do spread the word about this campaign. Talk to your friends and family and feel free to share away. Check out my previous campaigns and my social media accounts and please get in touch if you have any questions or suggestions.I hope we can continue to work together to make this world a better place. Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Zen Maker Lab Inc. started as a group of engineers, designers, and entrepreneurs back in 2013 who enjoyed the maker/hacker culture and shared ideas about their personal projects.  We found our passion in demonstrating our creations to the local community, young and old, and in teaching the concepts behind how they worked.  Over the last seven years we've been conducting science, technology, engineering, art, and mathematics (STEAM) programs across the Greater Vancouver Area encouraging students, staff, youth and parents to design, make, and play.  We had to pause our programs in schools and community centers for the time being because of COVID-19.  Our team was forced to pivot and begin working on a brand new project.


The DesignMakePlay Pack was designed to bring the maker space home.  Students will be able to build exciting and technically innovative projects while they learn the science behind them.  This pack has 3 sets of materials to design, make, and play with and accompanying worksheets and videos that simplify intricate concepts and get kids excited.  This pack offers a total of 30 hours of STEAM learning content.  This pack will provide you and your kids with a fun and exciting experience you can enjoy at home.  Students can watch Zen Maker Lab’s videos and perform the activities at their own pace while illustrating real improvement through real projects and sharing their experience at the dinner table.  For any kids interested in engineering and arts, this is the perfect kit for you!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Most of the designs and curricular materials are ready to go!  We are looking to raise $5,000 for the production and shipping of our DesignMakePlay Pack to eager customers. The project kits and lessons are designed for kids in the age of 8-12, however, even adults will have fun with them!

  • Perk 1 - Our Facilitator's guide
    This document is an online learning booklet for any kid at home that allows them to learn about STEAM at home.  This guide has over 100 pages and has 30 distinct lessons.

  • Perk 2 - LED Clock Project Kit
    The LED Clock was designed here at Zen Maker Lab.  Students will learn the fundamental elements of time, oscillation, counters, programming and more! All tools and parts  needed to assemble and use are included. Documentation and activity sheets are found online.

  • Perk 3 - StoMo Project Kit
    The Tripod and Back drop was designed and manufactured here at Zen Maker Lab.  Check out the fully 3D printed hinges.  This tripod can hold an IPAD.  Create cool stop motion videos while learning about important concepts related to art and design.  All tools assemble and run are included.  Documentation and activity sheets are found online.

  • Perk 4 - Floorball & Data Visualization Kit
    This kit comes with a floorball stick, 4 floor balls, a tape measure, and cones.  Learn about data visualization while exercising and having fun.  All tools assemble and run are included.  Documentation and activity sheets are found online.

  • Perk 5 - The DesignMakePlay Pack
    This kit includes our LED Clock Project Kit that educates students about programming and timers, our StoMo Project kit for stop motion videos, and our floorball stick that ensures students are getting their exercise! You'll also get access to all 15 videos and 15 worksheets related to our DMP pack, the Facilitators Guide, and one face shield.

  • Perk 6 - The Design Make Play Pack + PPE Safely Bundle
    This kit includes our LED Clock Project Kit that educates students about programming and timers, our StoMo Project kit for stop motion videos, and our floorball stick that ensures students are getting their exercise! You'll also get access to all the 15 videos and 15 worksheets related to the DMP pack and our Facilitators Guide. As a bonus, you can keep yourself and your kids safe with Zen Maker Lab's PPE! This includes 2 Adult Face shields and Masks and one additional Child's face shield and mask.

If we hit our goal, we'll use the funds to begin work on our next Design Make Play Pack and the produce more packs!

 

The Impact

Your contribution will go towards furthering a world where every child can build and create using science, technology, engineering, art, and mathematics (STEAM) safely from home.  Most jobs that exist today won't exist tomorrow and STEAM is important for getting kids prepared for a creative and innovative future.

The DesignMakePlay Pack keeps kids engaged in project based learning.  Our dream is to continue to inspire students to see what is possible when you apply the sciences in a fun and creative way. Your investment helps build that dream despite these tough times and allows us to continue to create content and deliver our programs.

 

Risks & Challenges

There are many STEAM kits and toys out there but many are lacking substance beyond a cool thing to build. We believe that the DesignMakePlay pack is better than anything out there now because we've included in-depth lessons around each kit and blend designing and playing into STEM in interesting ways.  We want kids to be innovative, creative and healthy in a way other STEAM projects don’t. Our kits are closely tied to the Canadian Curriculum.  We've invested time into reading through Canadian curriculums for every province across Canada and aim to provide lessons with our kits that can be effective for teaching concepts and terms relevant to students' education and grade level in school.

We want our kids' education to be relevant for their careers later in life which can be difficult to know.  Zen Maker Lab Inc. provides services to industry such as 3D design, PCB design, 3D printing, laser cutting, programming, prototyping and more.  This allows us to keep an active pulse on industry and know what's important for students in the future.  Our service work also introduces our team to new challenges and innovative ideas that inspire our projects.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The easiest way to contribute to our campaign is to share with friends and colleagues! 
You can also check out our website to see our other services and products:
https://www.zenmakerlab.com/

We have free shows and more on Youtube:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7TEs8HjuZvKk7...\

You can stay up to date with us on Twitter:  
https://twitter.com/ZenMakerLab

Check out our Instagram:
https://www.instagram.com/zenmakerlab/
