the year
             ·Accommodation
in the school residences for the year
             · Food
             · Books and
revision materials
             · A little
monthly stipend
Your support is important to these students.
We intend to directly send all the money raised to the school
account in collaboration with the school principal. We believe all donations
are relevant, therefore, all money will be sent whether or not our goal is met. 



Why is Your Contribution Important?

The community we are working to change is one that has had a very negative school enrollment and very huge numbers of dropouts. In fact, only one has managed to get into the university (David, the founder EducationHOPE). Among the factors, the main one is the poverty levels that are so high in this community, literally every household lives on less than $1 every day. So many students cannot go to school because their families cannot afford to pay their school fees, a necessity since education has to be paid for by students in Kenyan high schools.

Imagine the impact you are creating not only for the students but for their families and also their communities. Educating one child can change the world, but you are going beyond this with your support to create a motivation, show a possibility and beyond all this, building a future for someone whom without you cannot make it.
With your support, these students will forget the trouble and worry of being sent out of school and instead peacefully stay in school just like their fellow students.
Help us make the difference


The Story. 

About Majimbo


Majimbo, a little island located in the northeastern part of Lake Victoria in the western part of Kenya just next to Uganda is approximately 5km2. In a distance, beauty shines to its maximum. In fact it is one of the best places to watch the breathtaking scenery of sunsets in the Western horizon in Kenya; the reflection of the burning skies by the Lake in the evenings presents an amazement of nature. It is one of these regions on earth with some of the best smiles I have ever seen in my life.
Despite the abundance of life of nature in Majimbo, an agony is rooted deep in the lifestyles of the people it hosts. Within this hidden beauty, a hidden story lies. Stories of great yearning and need although in ignorance, a life lived without a hope of a tomorrow although a knowledge of its existence. A daily life with no electricity, no cars or motorbikes, no clean water, no system for waste and sewage (which crazily pollutes the water where their livelihood, the tilapia and the Nile perch, comes from), there is no trust in one another, no shoes, no lunches and no decent clothes for the kids, they wear some dirty and ready-to-retire uniforms that have been in circulation for longer than the wildly fluctuating Kenyan Shilling. Shacks are built of manure or corrugated iron sheets and randomly found-and-resurrected bits and bobs. There are about two bicycles (from a different century), dirt tracks that get flooded and impossible to go through after a big rain, there is HIV left and right, polygamy and widow-inheritance which, of course plays the biggest role in the spread of HIV, there are qualified but frustrated and unmotivated teachers who will wonder for the rest of their days why they spent so much money and time on college when they will never make it back unless they become headmasters and will be in the position to play with government and charity money.  (Imagine the impact of this on educating the kids). There are some wild ideas on life and existence, there are some very unusual beliefs, rituals, customs (some of which only contribute to the health issues), there is no motivation, there are no ideas or inspiration and if there is a spark of inspiration, there is no one to implement the ideas. Most people dream only about simple survival. Imagination is nearly dead. Everything stands still, frozen in time.
Each day passes and as time goes the exact definition of Majimbo´s contents of life rarely defines itself; for of reality, a harsher condition of life continues to dominate. On average seven out of ten students who enroll in the community primary school drop out before graduating, and out of those who graduate, very few of them join high schools due to poor performances and the incapacity to afford high school education... None of the girls in this community are educated. They either drop out of school as young as 15 to get married to fellow teens who are dropouts too or get pregnant somewhere on the way before reaching grade 8. Without education, a future is not created, a community is under extinction and this is what this community faces. Among these factors, comes HIV/AIDS which has impacted this community so negatively; ranging from reduced labor to loss of lives each time. Not ignoring the agony of this deadly disease, the people contribute to its spread although in ignorance but in the name of cultural practice and customs which illiteracy highly contributes to. Widow inheritance, polygamy and not observing AIDS prevention mechanisms especially with self-care in matrimonial lives.  The effects of these factors and the disease itself continue to live in this community and possibly forever if something is not done. I would take a moment to imagine 10 years from now and think about all the 10-15 year old children, if we do not take them to school, this is the lifestyle they will be living; all will be married with at least two children or two wives or would have married more than two wives of whom they will be living with none of them. This means that at least 60% of them to more than 70% of the youths in Majimbo today will have HIV/AIDS. They will also be working so hard fishing in the dangerous Lake Victoria to feed their families. If the reverse happens and all of them go to school, maybe only a few of them will be married, the probability that any of them will be HIV/AIDS positive will be highly reduced, none of them will be in the lake fishing but rather in school looking for opportunities and possibly just as I do, at least some of them will be out there in the world looking for opportunities for this community to make it better.
Out of Majimbo this year something unusual happened, it is surprising! Since when I got out of high school in 2011, only two have been admitted after me. All who have managed to graduate from high school after me did not join high school, either for financial or performance reasons. This year more than 20 students performed well and were admitted to high schools. This in a very great manner was contributed to by the motivation I gave the students while in school, after winning a MasterCard Foundation Scholarship to study abroad. Out of those who graduated with good grades are two girls who because they could not afford their school, one decided to run away from her home and get married while the other is now pregnant; both aren´t in school. The rest of the students who are now all admitted to Got Agulu Secondary School, the nearest high school in Majimbo has one major worry; how they will be able to stay in school until they graduate and how will they achieve their dreams after this long struggle. The bottom-line is the amazing motivation they have had to generate to overcome the demanding and harsh conditions to graduate from primary school with good marks and grades. This is reason enough to paint the picture of the kind of determination and passion in the minds of each of these students. They are all from very poor family backgrounds with some of them being orphans while others literally have to also work with their parents to enable them to at least get a single meal in a day. By this, they literally have not enough time to study as day-scholars and with the conditions, a number of them are forced to miss even school. Already, even after only staying in school for two months, most of them have been forced to stay out of school because of the huge outstanding fee balances they already have yet their families cannot afford to pay. These students represent an array of diversity and varied conditions that although related are very different. 

Sample Stories
Edward Mahala


16-year-old Edward Mahala is the only child of a young couple who died just six years after the birth of their son. The couple who later died of HIV/AIDS after the young Edward was able to walk around the yard and enjoy the life of every toddler luckily did not infect their baby with the disease but the effect of their absence was felt just immediately after the father who died a year after the mother was just taken back to the soil. No one despite knowing the real need the young innocent Edward needed was ready to take him in to take care of him; the reason being the huge stigma this deadly disease held at that time. Indeed the grandmother with whom he lives today says that not even his uncles were ready to hear his story, they would literally evade it if they had to hear the name Edward. The poor little Edward was too innocent even to guess this. Two days later after all the people were to get back to their homes as the Luo culture demands after the burial of the dead, the grandmother took the little boy. She did not know how she was going to take care of him although she says she was in love with the angel after no one else was ready. She does not have a husband and two of her children are also suffering from this deadly disease. She did not have a job but largely depended on the help from the elder son who owns a boat at the lake. She was ready to share the little help she would always receive. Edward has since then grown into a boy ready to make her grandmother proud but still he cannot pay his school fees, neither can his grandmother.
John
Maduri 




From a very early stage in his life, he was outstanding and his level of curiosity would make him stand out. Now, he wants to be a doctor but what is so attractive about John is his friendliness and ability to build cohesion with new people of all kinds. During his stay in his primary school, every teacher was impressed with his ability to lead, discipline and level of maturity even at that young age.
John is a fourteen-year-old boy from a very humble background. His father who is now 87 years old never had an opportunity to even go midway through the elementary school and neither did the mother have an opportunity to step into the elementary school class. Subsequently, never did his parents make any savings for him or for his two elder brothers to take them to school. With his good performance, he received an admission to one of the provincial schools in the region but because of financial problems he could not get in but went to the cheaper school near home where he could stay as a day-scholar.
John has two brothers, the elder who after doing his high school exams did not do very well and seven years later still does not have a job. The other just got a scholarship to study outside the country after having taken his exam in 2011. John really needs to be in school as he dreams to build his parents a good life but yet faces a lot of challenges to pay his fees as none of his parents can work.
Nicholas Lwande



Nicholas is the first born of a very young couple who live on donated land so far apart separated from their ancestral home. His grandfather separated from what they call a family and so they are today. Neither of his parents ever went to school and they get their daily bread from fishing which in reality no longer has value in Majimbo. From the early stages in their lives Nicholas and his other five siblings have had to miss school to fish and also in a manner take part in the maintenance of the family. Even before starting school, Nicholas was a ¨professional¨ when it comes to fishing as he would always accompany his father any moment the mother was not in a position to do so. This has made him and his siblings miss a lot of days in school. None of his parents take the education of the children serious and the motivation that each of the children has is what keeps them moving along the academic path. In fact, one of his cousins already dropped out of school to help in the family upkeep while the brother had to repeat grade 8 this year because the parents could not afford to pay for their studies.
This boy has a unique dream. In fact, judging from the family conditions he has grown up from he would not even know of surgery but when asked what he wants to be, he says he wants to study to become a surgeon and help those people who want operations.

Dennis Ogilo




Dennis is an embodiment of an incredible possibility and indeed a representation of defying the odds. With all the generations of his family, he is the first of the family to get into a high school despite being an orphan. Indeed, none of the family members has ever taken the primary national exams but all dropout at the fifth or sixth grade to get into the Lake. Every male in the family of Dennis is a fisherman from the grandparents and so amazingly Dennis has broken this cycle so uniquely.
Dennis is one person you would conclude is completely intelligent. Being an orphan and living with one of the uncles, he has to go fishing just like the other members in the family hence missing school on a regular basis and despite that he still managed being among the best students. Literally, there is no one who is going to pay for his education despite his moving determination and brightness. He is among those whom I call a motivation despite having gone through the same environment just because the energy that he carries is an incredible one.




Challenges

 We believe that being a believer in education and a creator of hope for a rural child, you deserve an updated information on how those whom you support are advancing towards their dreams, we know the best way to keep you updated is through having a website where you can visit any moment or have email newsletters. We are in the process of making our website since we intend to impact the lives of many other children through your support not only in Majimbo but all through Africa and when the website is done later this year, we will keep you all updated.
    
Other Ways You Can Help 
The success of this needs you in all the following ways.
You have some friends, family members who may help bring hope to the rural poor children? Share with them through personal emails.
You have classmates who have seen the importance and fruits of being a class? They too may want to help others sit in a classroom and change their lives.
You have colleagues who have seen the sweet fruits of education? They will definitely be interested in sharing the hope and help many others experience it. Share the word
Use the indiegogo share tools like Facebook, Twitter to reach out to friends, write a blog or use Google+ about this and get the word going.
You can like us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/ruralkidhope to get updates on all the information regarding the impact you have made.
Thank you very much for being part of this and being part of the campaign to create a better future in the rural Africa.

story:
If you have kids or grand kids, you need ROOT. Teaching a child to read using a finger to point out letters, phonics and words can be inaccurate and lead to confusion about what to read. ROOT solves this. ROOT is an innovative tool that helps anyone from moms and dads to teachers focus developing readers on all aspects of language; words, letters, phonics, sentences, and punctuation, using light to highlight it. ROOT will change the way learners absorb information. My name is Chad and I thank you for looking at ROOT, named because I personally watched it grow the “roots of reading competency.” I'm a married dad of two boys working hard to make this invention come true and hope you support this awesome idea.

Like myself many adults toil with teaching children to read but love the time spent with them and a great book. ROOT makes learning easier and turns reading into a fun and interactive activity for any young child. Say goodbye to distracting fingers crossing the page and accidentally covering parts of words. ROOT clearly highlights exactly what is to be read or understood including hard to learn consonant digraphs like the ch, sh and th sounds. It's a virtual highlighter you use in place of a pointer or fingertip.



We live in a world where literacy can be the difference between success and failure. By supporting ROOT you will become the catalyst for improving a child’s life somewhere. Be it your own child or a donated device to a reader in need, you’ll be a part of something powerful and far reaching. Being a ROOT supporter will ensure this amazing device finds its way into the world community.

How was ROOT born, my story.

I invented ROOT for my youngest son after months of teaching him the old fashioned way using my finger to point out phonics and break down complex words. One night I had the idea to use a small flashlight and point the unfocused beam on letters and phonics, using a playing card to "cut off" the light on the edges. It didn't work very well, but I had discovered the power of light and knew I just needed to harness it. Once I realized what I wanted to accomplish, I spent hours at the hardware store picking through everything, ultimately buying enough odds and ends to build the prototype. The next few days were spent making what would become ROOT, cutting parts and using duct tape and sticky putty getting the light to focus as necessary. Although the prototype was not pretty, nor as accurate as the professionally engineered ROOT, it was enough to teach my young boy to read. I knew I was on to something spectacular.


The current design is carefully crafted and engineered with hours of research and development. A lot of time was invested in ROOT to simplify the experience and make it fun for the reader. Its size was designed so it’s both comfortable and easy to use. When you hold ROOT in a writing position, the “feather touch” slider allows for smooth operation. Small thumb movements change the shape of the light from a square highlighting one letter to the rectangle spanning an entire word or words. The light is intended to highlights a letter, phonic, one word, punctuation or perhaps the first part of a complex compound word. I can also be used to help solve math problems, highlight complex scientific equations and even teach music. Afraid of losing it? Me too, that’s why ROOT will have a sturdy clip so you can affix it to the cover of a book. The working prototype of ROOT just needs a few minor improvements.





Phase 1 will be handled by myself and an engineering company in Longmont, Colorado. For phase 2 we may use backer input so please get in touch! Phase 3 will be a traditional relationship with a manufacturer most likely sourced in China. I have sourced manufacturing before and my engineering company will also help out. Survey and campaign management will be done with Backerkit.com and shipping will likely be outsourced to a company like Fulfillrite.com to ensure proper and timely delivery. Fulfillment costs have been accounted for in the shipping and handling fee. There is a $5,000 reserve to cover any unexpected expenses.

In closing

Once a child learns to read it opens up a whole new world. Please join me and help ROOT become a reality by funding today at any level. I would love to have you play a part in changing the world one child at a time.

ROOT is Patent Pending and protected under US Patent Law.

Perks in Pictures:

story:
Short Summary

:

  • My name is Diego Gonzalez and im an artist from the midwest Chicagoland area. I grew up poor in a small town and I always wanted to be an artist when I grew up. I was lucky enough get a few art scholarships when I was a kid and had the help of many great people along the way.
  •  Now I'm fortunate to say I am a professional artist and my work has been featured on the Airbrush Action Magazine's website, The book "The Business of Airbrushing by Mickey Harris", Convergence Art Magazine and C2E2 Chicago Comic CON as well as many other publications thanks to good contributors like you!
  •  Your contribution can make a huge impact on the lives of a children! 


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • I need at least  $2000 to buy airbrush materials and art supplies for the class. With these tools the kids can actually start generating there own money by making shirts, temporary airbrush tattoos, and other airbrush products.  Temporary tattoos are easy to do and are a huge hit at high school games.
  • My perks are one of a kind original pieces of art. They are a limited edition shirts, hats, prints and skate deck series. 
  • The funds will go to the RIver Forest school system Art Department in Lake Station Indiana. If I raise more money I can hopefully be able to fund another school system Edison High school in Lake station. 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a huge impact on these kids lives! This is a wonderful opportunity to make a real difference in a community and at the same time help show your support and appreciation for the arts. Basic supplies like oil paints, new brushes , pens , paper and materials go along way to make a big difference :

  • From one mural project ( a similar school system Project)completed successfully I have had the chance to do others around the area.
  • You get the chance to make a tangible difference in the lives of these kids
  • you support the arts and culture.

Risks & Challenges

Some of the challenges I face is raising money within the community that does not have much money to give and the arts are  usually the most underfunded programs within a community. 

  • I am now a professional artist and operate a small business that I can use to help promote my project to raise money.
  • I am networking on all of my social media outlets, reaching out to the community,donating cool perks from my business.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Hola.

Our names are Fionna and Stefania. We are currently undergraduate students at SUNY Cortland. We are both studying Psychology, and hope to pursue careers in the direction of Child Advocacy, Counseling and International Affairs. We are members of our Student Government Association on campus, and are involved with our community as well. We are focused young professionals, who in the last semester met through interning at an Aid to Victims of Violence program, working as crisis intervention advocates for victims of domestic and sexual violence . Now, we are embarking on a new project. We have  been accepted into a short term program through an organization called Global Volunteer Networks, where we will be teaching English in a Peruvian orphanage. We are trying to fundraise part of the cost of our trip, since it costs quite a bit of money to house and feed the volunteer workers. The trip will cost about $1,200 per person. The money will also be going towards books and clothing for the children, that we plan on bringing with us. We are hoping that with steps like this, such as traveling to Peru to volunteer, we can one day achieve our dream of starting our own non-profit organization. 

Our philosophy is UBUNTU.

Unbuntu is the belief that we are defined by the compassion and kindness we give to others. 

We hope to carry that in our work, and in this journey to Peru, where we will be short term volunteers , providing education for children.  We will be teachers. Please go like the Facebook page for more information on other fundraisers and traveling that we do.

End Sex Trafficking and Modern Day Slavery

If you have any questions, comments or concerns please call


607 423 7794 or contact

fionna.hart@cortland.edu

stefania.buta@cortland.edu



Stay blessed !

story:
MATTKEL REGENERATIVE CENTER (MKRC) has its origin from two (2)  creative, resourceful, prolific and spontaneous young men (Matthew Amechi  Onyeanula and Innocent Kelvin Coffie).

Matthew Amechi Onyeanula is a Nigerian born (Citizen from Lagos, Nigeria)  was educated in Nigeria/Ghana. He has been opportune to work/volunteer in different organizations in Nigeria/Ghana and now a certified Permaculturist.

Innocent Kelvin Coffie is a  Ghanaian, born and raised in the Volta Region, once a teacher in Akosombo Eastern Region, now a Farm Manager/Permaculturist

VISION

Our vision is of humanity living in harmony with a functioning ecosystem. Our goal is to establish a regenerative agriculture and permaculture demonstration center within the Kyrehi community of Kintampo South in the Brong Ahafo Region in Ghana.

MISSION

Our earth ecosystem is in shambles. Healthy ecosytems are fundermental to sustainable business and vibrant and social communities; indeed peoples health and well being are intricately linked with the Earths health and well being. These issues need to be addressed. Our Mission is to address this by:

Experimenting with and demonstrating possible solutions to problems faced by poor Kyrehi community farmers such as degraded land, dependency on erratic weather patterns, and lack of resources (capital, education, tools, etc.). 

Increase soil fertility and biodiversity in the broader community landscape , making the land more productive for future generations by sharing and spreading techniques and technologies we are currently working with to achieve our mission including the following:

Natural building, bee keeping and agro-forestry systems, chicken tractors, greenhouses, micro terraces, contour ditches, edible forest gardens, sustainable animal management, rainwater catchment, low cost irrigation systems, intensive gardens, greywater systems, composting, passive solar energy, value added product development, etc.

BUDGET

  • Land (2 acres): $1000


Risks and challenges

One of our greatest challenges is the socio-economical difficulties that Africa faces. Deforestation and land degradation creates food security issues for many Ghanaians . Often However, the individuals who would benefit most from what we are teaching are also those who are least able to afford a permaculture education. We are meeting this challenge by offering the most affordable education we can. As a non-profit organization, we also intend to minimize our expenses and reinvest our profits to further improve the accessibility of a permaculture education.

A potential risk that our project faces is a downturn in the local and global economy. Ghanaians and internationals alike are less likely to invest in self-education or consider other techniques in trying times. Ironically, if this happens what we are teaching is even more valuable (i.e. making home, garden and business more resilient and productive). Thus this risk also comes with great opportunity,
story_txt:
MATTKEL REGENERATIVE CENTER (MKRC) has its
origin from two (2)  creative, resourceful, prolific and spontaneous young
men (Matthew Amechi  Onyeanula and Innocent Kelvin Coffie). Matthew
Amechi Onyeanula is a Nigerian born (Citizen from Lagos, Nigeria) 
was educated in Nigeria/Ghana. He has been opportune to work/volunteer in
different organizations in Nigeria/Ghana and now a certified Permaculturist.
Innocent Kelvin Coffie is a  Ghanaian, born and raised in the Volta
Region, once a teacher in Akosombo Eastern Region, now a Farm
Manager/Permaculturist
VISION
Our vision is of humanity living in harmony with
a functioning ecosystem. Our goal is to establish a regenerative
agriculture and permaculture demonstration center within the Kyrehi community
of Kintampo South in the Brong Ahafo Region in Ghana.
MISSION
Our earth ecosystem is in shambles. Healthy
ecosytems are fundermental to sustainable business and vibrant and social
communities; indeed peoples health and well being
are intricately linked with the Earths health and well being. These
issues need to be addressed. Our Mission is to address this by:
Experimenting with and demonstrating possible
solutions to problems faced by poor Kyrehi community farmers such as degraded
land, dependency on erratic weather patterns, and lack of resources (capital,
education, tools, etc.). 
Increase soil fertility and biodiversity in the
broader community landscape , making the land more productive for future
generations by sharing and spreading techniques and technologies we are
currently working with to achieve our mission including the following:
Natural building, bee keeping and agro-forestry
systems, chicken tractors, greenhouses, micro terraces, contour ditches,
edible forest gardens, sustainable animal management, rainwater catchment, low
cost irrigation systems, intensive gardens, greywater systems, composting,
passive solar energy, value added product development, etc.
BUDGET
Land (2 acres): $1000 

Risks and challenges
One of our greatest challenges is the socio-economical
difficulties that Africa faces. Deforestation and land degradation creates food
security issues for many Ghanaians . Often However, the individuals who would
benefit most from what we are teaching are also those who are least able to
afford a permaculture education. We are meeting this challenge by offering the
most affordable education we can. As a non-profit organization, we also intend
to minimize our expenses and reinvest our profits to further improve the
accessibility of a permaculture education.
A potential risk that our project faces is a
downturn in the local and global economy. Ghanaians and internationals alike
are less likely to invest in self-education or consider other techniques in
trying times. Ironically, if this happens what we are teaching is even more
valuable (i.e. making home, garden and business more resilient and productive).
Thus this risk also comes with great opportunity,

story:
The devastating 7.8 magnitude earthquake has left thousands of houses into rubble in my beloved country Nepal. Mllions of people are left with no food, drinking water and shelter.  Despite the funds, medical aid and support from all over the world, it is heartbreaking to see that many people in my hometown are still seeking help. A lot of people lost their houses leaving them homeless and with absolutely nothing to live on. People are living outside in the rain and sun with no shelter and no food. It is my appeal to please show support and donate so I can at least help these people get some shelter, drinking water, medicines, and food.  Any small help will make a huge difference in such a tragic time.

Together , let's pray for Nepal and help to support Nepal and people during this catastrophe.

This is my plan of action to target these areas.

Around 5871 and counting more people in Bhaktapur area are homeless and living without shelter. They lost their houses and all the belongings. Neither they have money to buy food nor shelter to cover their heads. My plans are to buy medicines, get safe drinking water, food and get proper shelter. 

Following is the data collected from local area and we expect to help hands to them.

Locaction               Homeless No of People Right Now

1) Golmodi                                                  80

2) Hanumanghat                                      89

3) Hanumanghat-1                                   120

4) Hanumanghat-2                                  115

5) Hanumanghat-3                                  140

6) Hanumanghat-4                                  40

7) Hanumanghat-5                                  81

8) Maheswori Ground                            2000

9) Kamalbinayak                                     600

10) Maheswori Ground-1                      1200

11) Chyamasingh Town Plan               80

12) Chyamasingh Town Plan-1          1000

And counting more...

story:
The Muncy Family 5th Grade Paper Making Tour

Over the last year, I've been traveling alone a lot making paper with different communities. Buttonfieldpress.com 

Over the next year  my family and I will be traveling together, making paper, and creating an opportunity to do geographically influenced curriculum as we homeschool Lily for the 5th grade. The tour will also be an opportunity to introduce her to education she might not receive in Texas public schools. 

Our first trip of the Muncy Family 5th Grade Tour begins in late July and will take us through OK, VA, WV, NC, TN, and Washington DC. As part of our curriculum we'll be visiting historical Native American sites as well as a few of the Smithsonians and Lily will be attending the Highlander Children's Justice Camp. We'll be making paper at the camp as well as a number of other communities including a couple GI Coffee Houses and some Friends of Dard Hunter.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1200.00 for a restrictive drying box, which will greatly improve the quality and drying time of our paper on this trip. The equipment will be supplied by famed paper making tool supplier Lee Mcdonald.

The additional $300 should help us get the rewards out and put a bit of gas in the tank to get the trip started. Once on the road the trip will be supported by the communities that we plan on making paper with. More info about our stops will be forthcoming in the next few weeks as the Indiegogo campaign rolls on.

If you donate we've got a few rewards on paper handmade from military uniforms to show our appreciation of your support.

The Impact

The contributions you make to this campaign will not only ensure that this trip is a success the drying equipment will also help our spring trip up the Pacific coast and every other paper making trip my family and I take.

Risks & Challenges

I have had difficulty getting rewards out in a timely manner for previous campaigns on crowdsource sites. Although I have always got them out I have admittedly been slow. This time around I am keeping it simple with only two reward tiers. This simplicity will help us make sure everything gets out. All of these rewards will be in the mail by the end of September 2015.

Other Ways You Can Help

Contact us if you think you might have a place to stay or a place in the Smoky Mountains that might want to make paper with us in early September.

story:
The Need Is Urgent

In the current education space, there is an over abundance of skills-based courses online and the content mix is overwhelming. There are just too many companies recreating the wheel without any clear differentiation. Furthermore, teachers are creating hours of educational content without any proof that students actually want what they’re offering and without any hope for compensation. Oh, and user engagement? Most users who sign up for online courses never complete their training.

Where It All Started

Three whole days of early mornings, late nights, cramped space and some motion sickness along the way brought us together on the Startup Bus. But what started out as a pitch and a crew of five strangers committing to build something completely new has quickly gained traction as the future of online learning. shar.ed is a content experience platform powering economic and educational opportunity for students and teachers. The need is great and the possibilities are endless. Help usher in the future of learning by making shar.ed a reality.

Welcome to shar.ed

Imagine a world in which people were just 10% more engaged. What happens when you're more effective at work, more present at school, excited about new opportunities and empowered to try more new things? Picture an educational experience unlike any other in which:

  • Users crowdsource what they want to learn
  • Experts tailor content they deliver to user demand
  • Teachers don't waste time producing unwanted content
  • Teachers are compensated for their time, based on relevancy and need
  • Users enjoy an engaging learning experience tailored to their unique interests

The shar.ed Movement

shar.ed is for everyone. Our early adopters are tech entrepreneurs, experts, educators, mentors, influencers, thought leaders - shar.ers. Our users are street smart scholars, self starters, hustlers seeking pointers, life hackers, entrepreneurs, makers and do-ers. We're eager to learn from the best and brightest and we're excited about curating our educational journey. We don't just want to take Digital Marketing 101, I want to know a successful entrepreneur's hacks for getting press placements and a killer social strategy in place to launch a startup. We don't just want Intro to Business Management, we want to learn how to negotiate a freelance contract, get a promotion and how to finally ask for a raise.

We all remember sitting in class with a teacher lecturing us while we looked out the window counting clouds. It doesn’t have to be that way. Envision the future where all learners have a voice in curating their education. Help shar.ed become a reality.

story:
(NEW) See Our Offsite Donations

These are donations that this exhibit has received offline for this project due to the preference of and/or accessibility to the donor. Unfortunately, the value collected by Indiegogo on the right does not reflect the amount we receive offline. However, providing this information here is necessary to the growth of this campaign. https://goo.gl/Ysa69i


Summary

Women For Action, is a  501c3 organization which  champions women and  educate on the obstacles they face to bridge cultural differences. We interview women-firsts, award-winning subjects and other innovators, all who are making socially conscious contributions which aid in closing the gap between genders.

We are launching the first of its kind, the Women's Equality Exhibit to promote under recognized women change-makers from different cultural backgrounds. This national exhibit, is an expansion of our interview series and a proposed educational exposition on contemporary women who are  making historic achievements. Also, it is a collaborative initiative in honor of Women For Action’s  mission to petition leaders to elevate the national holiday, August 26th -  Women’s Equality Day to a federal holiday which has received signature support from women’s organizations across the country.

The exhibit's launch on August 26th, Women's Equality Day,  will feature 15 close to life-size (48 x 32) portraits of 21st-century women leaders, along with their bios and interviews. With a mission to promote diversity and inclusion, the project selects women who reflect today's American population, which is a representation of the entire world!


What We Need & What You Get

Women For Action is looking to raise $20,000 to build this exhibit. This would enable us to launch the initial opening. Here is the breakdown:

  • 55% towards the materials to build exhibit- This would include materials needed for 15 stations centered around each heroine, technical equipment and rental space for the facility holding the exhibit.
  • 15% to operations cost,  
  • 10% to promotions,
  • 10% to transportation and storage,
  • 5% to rewards and
  • 4 to 5% to IndieGoGo- An approximate nonprofit rate based on if we will raise all or a portion of the funds.
Our unique perks include:  
  • A print copy of our painting exclusively for this campaign which is titled "Windows of Opportunity" and handpainted by Julene Allen, The Executive Director. The painting features six different women from different backgrounds. This artwork is a watercolor which includes gold leaf enamel that borders each woman's window.


  • Also, you can be the first to get tickets for this exhibit! Plus, they make great collectors items for this significant event. The location and city will be announced.

  • Be the first to get the copy of our limited edition magazine featuring watercolor drawings and a special message to girls from some of our heroines for this exhibit. It's such an exciting booklet for girls ages 5 to 17, or any young woman seeking inspiration.


  • We chose flexible funding. Flexible funding takes a larger percentage from our fundraising total if I do not raise all the funds. However, this exhibit will need all its funds. So it's important that we meet our fundraising goal to build a quality exhibit for women heroines.  

The Impact

Too often, women's efforts go unnoticed. For those with a social disadvantage, the magnitude is even greater. The Women's Equality Exhibit would extend Women For Action's mission to do public good by aiding women and girls in three different ways:

  1. It works against stereotypes and discrimination by promoting a diverse pool of women in leadership which could put women and girls at a social and political advantage. 
  2. By increasing the numbers of our heroines and elevating their roles to emphasize the impact they are making, expands the pathways for women and girls.
  3. Noting these women’s achievements sets the tone for prioritizing contributions made by women.

Our Featured Heroines

Bonnie-Jill Laflin, The First and Only Woman NBA Scout
Shuli Eshel, A Documentary filmmaker whose work has contributed to the women’s rights movement, politics and history in the United States and Israel
Audra Fordin, Founder of Women Auto Know©, an educational innovation for women car-owners
Zainab Khan, Global Women’s Rights Activist and Leading Artist whose work is being used for global nonprofits
Pam Erickson, Executive Director and Founder of Coastal Studies for Girls, a one of kind live- in leadership and marine science school in Maine  for girls 
Jen Gurecki, CEO of Coalition Snow, an innovative supplier of ski equipment for competitive women skiers. 
Edniesha Curry, Former WNBA and Europe basketball player and Founder of Coach Eddie Basketball

The objective is to spotlight women of significance who are a part of the American story- on our timeline, making history. We want to sound the bullhorn on new and amazing stories of women with  a conscious effort to promote diversity and inclusion. These trailblazers present new working models for 21st-century young women and girls especially as our society bolsters a future for equality!
Contributions made towards this exhibit builds a partnership between you and Women For Action to initiate a process which enables women’s voices to be heard, and society to be informed about more women who are reshaping our culture.

Building Alliances with the Community

Live solo performances from local women artists will be featured during key dates and times during the exhibit. We really want to extend the mission of inclusion to local women of talent. 


Other notes

This is Women For Action's first exhibit. However, we have sought out advice on how to build a quality educational exposition and have meticulously mapped out the materials needed for this project. Meeting our fundraising goal will enable us to incorporate an installation designer to aid us with our plans and other help needed.


Risks & Challenges

Some of the challenges this project may face is finding the right location to launch the first exhibit. Space is everything and location is key. With such an important effort, we need the right space and ideally a central location within a major city to set the tone for others. So we are keeping this in mind as we submit inquiries to locations to host the exhibit.  

Update! The city of Chicago is top on the list. Right now, we submitted a proposal to a location within downtown Chicago. It is very likely the exhibit will be here. Being said, it's a central location, accessible and free to the public. The success of the Women's Equality Exhibit's first launch, catapults a mission to build others in different cities.

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope that you can at least contribute a dollar to this campaign, but if you can't, don't worry there are other ways you can help!

  • You can spread the message of this campaign by sharing it with friends and family through email and social media. You can use the sharing buttons below.
  • You can login daily to see if we have reached our goals and tweet about it to keep the momentum going.
  • Don't forget to sign our petition to "Elevate Women's Equality Day to a federal holiday!" That's how this whole thing got started!  https://www.change.org/p/michelle-obama-elevate-women-s-equality-day-to-a-federal-holiday

Thank you so much! 


Our Websites:

www.womenforaction.org

http://photoexhibit.nationalwomensequalityday.com

story:
You Give.  They Read.  They Smile.  We Win.

This is not summer school, and it's so much more than a summer camp.  HAPPY Reading is answering a decades-old problem that is hurting America.  We help close the achievement gap by giving kids reading skills, confidence, hope, and HAPPINESS in just a few weeks.

This is not skill and drill.  This is a joyful exploration of history, science, sports, the arts, community service and so much more---through, with and for the sake of reading.  We lead children to a natural love for books by thinking outside the book.

We served 41 children last year.  32 attended for at least 2 weeks.  They saw MAJOR, measured gains in their ability and attitudes about reading.  This school year, reading and writing has been so much easier for them than ever before!  Help us to make reading HAPPY for even more young learners. 


Why this matters...

Poverty.  Unemployment.  Crime.  Incarceration.  Racism.  Bullying.  Questionable character.  Low self-esteem.  Fractured families.  Dysfunctional communities.

Name almost any problem that eats away at a cohesive, American fabric.  Think of all the reasons for underachievement and emotional distress.  Research tells us that for a large percentage of what's hurting us, poor reading skill is a common denominator.  Building a brighter future can be as simple as helping more kids become proficient readers...helping more families bond through books....giving more people access to the healing power of simple stories and helping them to unleash the creative genius we all have within.


We've started something special...

The achievement gap...the cavernous difference between the academic success of white, middle-class America and virtually everyone else.... has remained a persistent problem for decades. 

But guess what?  The newest research tells us there's NOT a huge difference in intelligence.  There's a difference in resources...especially in access to books,  intellectual stimulation and enrichment during the summer months.

Our camps address this by thinking outside the book and making reading another fun part of summer camp...with outstanding results.

This time next year...

 ...at least 20 kids will be better readers and writers than they are right now.  They will be stronger communicators and much HAPPIER about it...if you will help us.    We know this because of what we've seen with last year's campers. 

We served 41 children 32 of whom attended for at least two weeks.  Typical improvement was 3 guided reading levels.  All kids showed measurable improvement in reading or writing attitudes...most gained or improved a love for both.  Kids with longstanding literacy challenges have moved to "on grade level", read more books, earned better grades and reported better attitudes all of this school year.  Some even won school contests and awards for outstanding reading or writing. 

We want to raise enough money for AT LEAST 20 kids to attend summer reading camp for at least two weeks.  These are kids recommended by their schools for extra help.  These are kids who will be able to attend for FREE because of your generosity.

With your help...

...year 2 of our specialty camps will be even better than last year's.  We're looking for $10,000 to cover camp costs for location, staffing, materials, and camp essentials for 20 campers.  We would love to reach even more by exceeding our goal!  If you will make this investment in our project, we will deliver great results for the good of our campers and the good of our world.

For camp director credentials and for testimonials:  http://www.happyreadingcamp.com/campdirector.html

Parents' feedback:  

https://youtu.be/9fxIvmB4NN8

story:
SigmaCamp is an intensive one week hands-on science camp organized by scientists from Stony Brook University and Brookhaven National Lab. In our four years, we have grown from 40 students to 110 and even have a waitlist.  We are lucky to have full-time scientists from the top universities all over the world (such as MIT and Harvard) teaching at our camp. Instructors create elaborate labs for students to explore the fields of Science Technology Engineering Mathematics.  This campaign will finance our first quad copter project.  This opportunity will be an amazing motivator for boys and girls to become more interested in the complex study of STEM.

Funds Distribution

  1. ~ $2,000 – 4 Game of Drones quad copter kits, and transmitters for students to build and learn to fly.                                                                                                                  



  1. ~ $700 – spare parts, servos, and materials for students to build accessories for Quad V.S. Quad aerial combat and challenges.

  2. ~$1,000 – Game of Drone’s battle arena and other challenge accessories.

  3. ~$1,300 – Rock Stock Max 3D printer for students to design and manufacture parts for their quad copters.


                                 

 Total ~$5,000

Rewards

  1. All contributions are tax deductible

  2. We will have a poster with the names of all contributors at the arena and the size of your name or logo will depend on size of donation.  Join in with friends to make a group donation! 

Backup Plan

If we are not able to reach our goal, we will run a much less extensive quad copter workshop and remaining funds will go to other camp labs in need of funding and towards scholarships for students.

Our impact

Experiencing our workshop will teach students about  these new emerging industries in STEM.  This is a rare hands-on opportunity to build and fly quad copters for young creative people, who would not be able to learn this on their own.  We hope to expand this beyond just being a hobby. They will learn great engineering skills that can help these students in future academic endeavors.                               

                   




Risks and Challenges

  • We might have trouble teaching students how to fly without crashing, which will result in damage to parts and repair costs. We are qualified to overcome this since we expect to be able to teach people who have never flown a quad copter  in approximately 30 minutes.                                                                                                      


  



  • Difficulty in obtaining the funds we need might prevent us from offering this amazing opportunity to the budding scientists.

Other ways you can help.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

  • Tell your friends and family and get the word out.

  • Ask other people you know to join in with your pledge to increase your total contribution.

  • Offer to match funds that other people give for this worthy project

Thank you!

story:
Hi friends- I am passionate about ending hate and creating a better world for my family and yours.   I have worked with Hey U.G.L.Y.'s (unique, gifted, lovable, you) Co-Founder and President, Betty Hoeffner for the past few years and her strategies for empowering youth and her passion for preventing bullying and youth suicide is contagious. 

Recently I have been working on creating my own youth empowerment program to teach youth a variety of skills to deal with today’s pressures- topics that are not typically covered in the classroom.  I have asked for your suggestions, comments, feedback every step of the way.  This journey began years ago, but a fire was lit when I was working in Colorado for Falcon School District 49 and had the ability to organize a concert to end bullying- Stand Up. Speak Out. -working with several amazing non-profit organizations including Hey U.G.L.Y..  .- Unique Gifted Lovable You which was founded in 2002 under the name, Hey U.G.L.Y., Inc. It became a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization in 2004 under the name Hey U.G.L.Y., Inc. NFP.

Bullying has been proven to be a leading cause of youth violence, eating disorders, substance abuse, low grades, truancy, dropping out of school, self-injury and suicide. More than 160,000 students skip school each day because of it.  Bullying is not a rite of passage and should not be an expectation our children need to deal with.

Betty Hoeffner’s experience and talent are incredible.  I have used Hey U.G.L.Y. as the standard for which I was creating my program, and reached out to Betty to utilize some of the Hey U.G.L.Y. curriculum as a way to continue to spread awareness for her organization and while discussing my plans, an amazing thing happened-  Betty invited me to partner with Hey U.G.L.Y., forming a satellite branch in Chattanooga, Tennessee.  I am blown away – and I am going for it.

This nonprofit organization is dedicated to helping youth with self-esteem and empathy-building programs to empower them to be their true selves and part of the solution to bullying. The Hey U.G.L.Y. message has reached over a million students through their Stop Bullying Task Force Program Curriculum, Empathy Learning Activity Plans (ELAPs), Assembly Presentations, seminars, website, "Choose To Change" radio show, self-esteem-building contests, and work with schools, community organizations and youth development professionals. Their youth programs enable students to become an integral part in the teaching and learning process. Their website for students is HeyUGLY.org. The Educators website is PreventBullyingNow.org and a site for Parents is at HeyUGLY4Parents.org.  

 I have been an event planner, advocate, community organizer and fundraiser for more than 20 years as well as having personal experience with sexual assault and bullying.  I share Betty’s vision of helping youth, and certainly do not need to reinvent a phenomenal program that works.  I am trying to raise $7,000 to cover start-up costs for registration, technology, travel and supplies with the hopes of launching our first event in October 2015 during National Stop Bullying Month.

Please join me.  This program can be offered anywhere in the country. Where there is a need, we will find the way.

Thank you for your support and love.

Mindy

story:
The project goes a long way back…

We have been working on the Community Center’s development over the past four years and have completed the building’s foundation and part of the first floor, handcraft rock walls, an anti-seismic structure of iron and concrete. We installed a 4.5 kilometer and keep giving maintenance to an off-gravel road where previously no vehicle could reach the impenetrable area. Water sources have been recovered and we keep planting thousands of trees thus far. And we are ambitious and will like to see a sustainable and integrated model to todays life farming and communal life by planting thousands of trees more.


                   Our exciting goal !!!



To complete the construction of the Community Center’s main building . This protective two-story structure will include: a seminar hall, waiting area, volunteer’s quarters, health clinic and fortified roof. 

Why to build a center?

If you really want to know...

click here!

before you do that "take a good sit"

find out for your self the raw reality of such a beautiful place.

...so why to build a center. Because we are a group of friends who see a way out! and because we can build a center, because we live foot prints behind us where ever we are, such foot prints will dictate the course of the future of our world and at last but not the least, because the Q`eqchi deserve options and the opportunity to read/write and their children deserve to play and they deserve a childhood with dignity, with access to pure water, food, education and fun.


                                


And if you wish to understand further, look at how your life could be if you where to live  with a budget as the people in Guatemala have... Hunger and Tortillas


Long term goal, To encourage self-reliance by creating sustainable economical revenues while acting as a pilot program which neighboring communities can replicate on their own.  


Risks and Challenges

Weather, the high rainfall can slow us or even stop us for weeks as heavy construction material have to travel long ways, through rain forest. 

We value your feedback and this community-base initiative requires collaboration on every level. Would you like to contribute your expertise in the field? We are very open to hearing your thoughts and would facilitate assistance on the ground if required.


What is the Community Center for?

         Providing remote and basic health care services

Acting as a model of sustainability      

     Protecting the rainforest of Izabal

Encouraging sound environmental practices        

 Facilitating greater community support

Creating a safe birthing center      

              Exposure to music & art seminars                    


Installing empowerment, inspiration, and sharing within the community 


                     


Ultimately

We would like to provide an economically and sustainable community-based model for the indigenous population of Guatemala to progress 

on their own terms. 


We estimated last year the construction of the Community Center in Izabal, Guatemala (click here for location) to cost approximately $23,000 USD and we continue and look forward to achieve our goal. With your kind help in our last campaign 23 for 23,000 we raised US $ 6,682.00 minus 5% fee of Indiegogo, 3-5 % for Paypal transactions and on Credit cards 3% plus 30 cent per transaction.

This year we are aiming to collect what we need for construction materials,

US $ 17,927.00

Our work its carried out under volunteer basis and we 

have no administration cost.


Continuation of building of the Center has been scheduled for the third week of September 2015. We invite you to see this beautiful sanctuary for yourself and witness our dedicated work over the last 9 years to restore it’s fragile ecosystem. 

Your support is appreciated and every thought of care toward those less privileged is cherished dearly! And your volunteering engagement would show to others there's a way to prosperity and thoughtful environmental practices.

Thank you for helping us with this important project and allowing us

"to bring love, where love has never been”.


 


…for a brighter future and for a world filled with joy.

Viktor
any surplus of proceedings will be used for furniture, utilities and other items necessary for the center to get started.

story:
PAN is the annual magazine produced by the Caerleon campus students of English and Creative Writing at the University of South Wales. The publication showcases the work of the arts, photography and creative writing departments at the University and affiliated adult education classes. The magazine offers the first opportunity for many students to see their work published, acting as an impetus for them to really produce their best work. PAN will be distributed across all of the University's campuses, as well as to adult education outlets.

As well as providing content to PAN, the whole enterprise is funded through student efforts. We have spent the year shaking buckets, organising events and approaching sponsors and advertisers in an effort to cover the production costs and are now spreading our net wider than the student community. If you are a writer or photographer or designer who knows how hard it is to get published, perhaps you could help us. You may be an ex-student who has fond memories of Caerleon or just someone out there who wants to help our cause.

Our target is £750.00 and whether we reach that in one lump sum or hundreds of small amounts, we will be eternally grateful. To show our thanks, we will;

Post a 'Thank You' on Facebook for those who donate £5.00+

Post a 'Thank You' on Facebook and send a copy of PAN to those who donate £10.00+

Post a 'Thank You' on Facebook and send a copy of PAN with a printed 'Thank You' inside to those who donate £20.00+


Even if you don't donate, thank you for taking the time to visit our page.

story:
Help the Belorussian Theater "Sunshine Kids" for Children with Down syndrome to pay for their travel to the Folklore Festival in Smizany, Slovakia.

"Auffallend viele Menschen mit Down-Syndrom haben besondere Fähigkeiten im Bereich des Sozialverhaltens und der Emotionalität, die bereits im Kleinkindalter beobachtet werden können. So wurde in Studien festgestellt, dass „viele dieser Kinder deutliche Stärken im sozialen Funktionieren“ zeigen und „öfter eine aufgeweckte Stimmungslage haben, mehr auf Musik ansprechen und weniger anstrengend sind als gleichaltrige andere Kinder“." – Wikipedia

Ich weiss nicht, wie es in anderen Ländern so ist, aber in Weissrussland gibt es nicht viel, was die Integration und die Sozialisation von Kindern mit Besonderheiten in der Entwicklung, im Speziellen mit dem Down Syndrom, fördern würde. Je älter die Kinder werden, desto einsamer werden sie, desto weniger Möglichkeiten gibt es für sie, sich am sozialen Leben irgendwie zu beteiligen. Alles, was in die Richtung gemacht wird, wird vor allem durch die Eltern solcher Kinder angestossen. So wurde im Jahr 2009 durch Elterninitiative das Theater «Sonnenscheinkinder» gegründet. Das Theater nimmt Kinder und junge Erwachsene mit dem Down Syndrom als Schauspieler auf.

Die wohl wichtigsten Personen, die dafür sorgen, dass das Theater auch weiterhin existiert und Auftritte hat, sind Olga Protasevitsch (Leiterin des Vereins «Down Kinder») und Svetlana Aleksandrovna Jacevitsch-Podlivaltseva (Regisseurin des Theaters).

Das Theater lebt durch Spenden und ehrenamtliche Beteiligung. Es ist inzwischen 5 Jahre alt und hat 11 Sonnenscheinkinder im Alter zwischen 4 und 33 Jahren. Sie haben schon 4 verschiedene Aufführungen vorbereitet und sind dabei ihre 5. Aufführung zu stemmen. Die Eltern versuchen immer neue Auftrittsmöglichkeiten für die Truppe zu organisieren, denn jeder Auftritt macht den jungen Schauspielern eine riesige Freude und bringt ihnen das Gefühl, ein funktionierender und nützlicher Teil der Gesellschaft zu sein.

Diese Aktion soll dem Theater "Sonnenscheinkinder" helfen, die Busfahrt (04.06 – 07.06.2015) zu einem Folklore Festival in der Stadt Smizany in der Slowakei zu bezahlen. Am 07.06.  soll der Auftritt des Theaters stattfinden, die Tage davor haben die Kinder ein kulturelles Erholungsprogramm. Für die Fahrt werden 2500 Euro benötigt. Der ursprüngliche Sponsor hat knapp einen Monat vor dem Event abgesagt. Die Vereinsleiterin hat es geschafft, noch jemanden zu finden, der bereit war 1000 Euro zu spenden. Es fehlen aber noch weitere 1500 Euro, die durch diese Aktion hoffentlich zusammenkommen werden.

Hier sind noch ein Paar  informative Links:

  • http://downsyndrome.by/association/30 - Website des Vereins «Down Syndrom» und des Theaters «Sonnenscheinkinder». Leider ist  hier alles  nur auf Russisch.
  • https://www.facebook.com/OKC.Smizany/posts/818335584886222:0 - Festivalprogramm auf Facebook

Vielleicht trifft diese Aktion auch auf jemanden, der ähnliche Vereine kennt und einen Austausch oder einen Auftritt für die Gruppe organisieren könnte.

Ich hoffe jedenfalls, dass die Fahrt und der Auftritt der Sonnenscheinkinder auf dem  Folklore Festival gerettet werden können.
story_txt:
Help the Belorussian Theater "Sunshine Kids" for Children with Down syndrome to pay for their travel to the Folklore Festival in Smizany, Slovakia."Auffallend viele Menschen mit Down-Syndrom haben besondere Fähigkeiten im Bereich des Sozialverhaltens und der Emotionalität, die bereits im Kleinkindalter beobachtet werden können. So wurde in Studien festgestellt, dass „viele dieser Kinder deutliche Stärken im sozialen Funktionieren“ zeigen und „öfter eine aufgeweckte Stimmungslage haben, mehr auf Musik ansprechen und weniger anstrengend sind als gleichaltrige andere Kinder“." – WikipediaIch weiss nicht, wie es in anderen Ländern so ist, aber in Weissrussland gibt es nicht viel, was die Integration und die Sozialisation von Kindern mit Besonderheiten in der Entwicklung, im Speziellen mit dem Down Syndrom, fördern würde. Je älter die Kinder werden, desto einsamer werden sie, desto weniger Möglichkeiten gibt es für sie, sich am sozialen Leben irgendwie zu beteiligen. Alles, was in die Richtung gemacht wird, wird vor allem durch die Eltern solcher Kinder angestossen. So wurde im Jahr 2009 durch Elterninitiative das Theater «Sonnenscheinkinder» gegründet. Das Theater nimmt Kinder und junge Erwachsene mit dem Down Syndrom als Schauspieler auf.Die wohl wichtigsten Personen, die dafür sorgen, dass das Theater auch weiterhin existiert und Auftritte hat, sind Olga Protasevitsch (Leiterin des Vereins «Down Kinder») und Svetlana Aleksandrovna Jacevitsch-Podlivaltseva (Regisseurin des Theaters).Das Theater lebt durch Spenden und ehrenamtliche Beteiligung. Es ist inzwischen 5 Jahre alt und hat 11 Sonnenscheinkinder im Alter zwischen 4 und 33 Jahren. Sie haben schon 4 verschiedene Aufführungen vorbereitet und sind dabei ihre 5. Aufführung zu stemmen. Die Eltern versuchen immer neue Auftrittsmöglichkeiten für die Truppe zu organisieren, denn jeder Auftritt macht den jungen Schauspielern eine riesige Freude und bringt ihnen das Gefühl, ein funktionierender und nützlicher Teil der Gesellschaft zu sein.Diese Aktion soll dem Theater "Sonnenscheinkinder" helfen, die Busfahrt (04.06 – 07.06.2015) zu einem Folklore Festival in der Stadt Smizany in der Slowakei zu bezahlen. Am 07.06.  soll der Auftritt des Theaters stattfinden, die Tage davor haben die Kinder ein kulturelles Erholungsprogramm. Für die Fahrt werden 2500 Euro benötigt. Der ursprüngliche Sponsor hat knapp einen Monat vor dem Event abgesagt. Die Vereinsleiterin hat es geschafft, noch jemanden zu finden, der bereit war 1000 Euro zu spenden. Es fehlen aber noch weitere 1500 Euro, die durch diese Aktion hoffentlich zusammenkommen werden.Hier sind noch ein Paar  informative Links:

http://downsyndrome.by/association/30 - Website des Vereins «Down Syndrom» und des Theaters «Sonnenscheinkinder». Leider ist  hier alles  nur auf Russisch.


https://www.facebook.com/OKC.Smizany/posts/818335584886222:0 - Festivalprogramm auf Facebook

Vielleicht trifft diese Aktion auch auf jemanden, der ähnliche Vereine kennt und einen Austausch oder einen Auftritt für die Gruppe organisieren könnte.Ich hoffe jedenfalls, dass die Fahrt und der Auftritt der Sonnenscheinkinder auf dem  Folklore Festival gerettet werden können.

story:
Project Overview

We are Jazz Empowers, a 501c3 non-profit based in Nashville with the mission to empower students to escape education inequality and poverty through jazz education.   We achieve this mission by starting and running after school jazz bands in Title 1 schools.

We are extremely excited to be going into two charter schools, Valor Collegiate and Nashville Prep for the 2015-2016 school year!  Both of these schools have never had any instrumental music programs, so most of the students in these jazz bands will be playing music for the first time.  We will be having two  rehearsals every week throughout the school year where students will learn how to play the fundamentals of jazz.   However, in order to prepare the students for these rehearsals we are providing all 50 students with free summer lessons.

Your contribution will help us fund these summer lessons.  Contributions will go towards paying our highly qualified instructors and buying a set of music stands for each school.  

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1,500 to cover the cost of the summer lessons.  $1,200 of this will go towards paying our instructors for their time and expertise and the other $300 will go towards buying music stands for both schools.  Each donation of $40 will help us fund an hour long lesson for 4-7 students. Each donation of $10 will help us a buy a music stand.

Playing music can drastically change a student’s life.  Your donation will help unlock the potential of 50 middle school students who are very excited to be learning jazz for the first time.  In addition, if you become a donor we will keep you updated on how your donation is making a positive impact on our students’ lives.

If we are unable to reach our entire goal, we will still use what money we did raise to support our summer lessons.

The Impact

Dozens of studies show that learning music can boost both students' academic performance and social development.  In a recent study in Metro Nashville Public Schools, students who participated in at least one year of music had 16% higher college entrance exam scores, 15% higher GPAs, and a 51% higher graduation rate compared to their peers who were not involved in any music activities.   

We have had 50 students sign up to participate in jazz band between the two schools, which is the potential for 50 lives to be transformed through jazz, one of America's greatest cultural contributions to the world.

Risks & Challenges

Nashville Prep and Valor Collegiate are the first schools we have worked in without a previous instrumental music program.   While this has provided some challenges since we are helping building their music programs from the ground up, we have already seen success because of the passion and dedication from donors, families, and the schools' administrations. We have already been able to secure instruments for all our students and we have hired highly qualified instructors with degrees in music education and/or jazz studies.   With the continued support from our community and high quality teaching from our instructors, we are confident that we will continue to see success in building up the jazz programs at Valor and Nashville Prep.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, don't worry you can still be a supporter of our cause! Support us by sharing our campaign to your network of friends and colleagues.   We appreciate your support!

story:
Short Summary

Help us breed a new generation of UK based shoemakers!

Our aim is to teach and inspire enthusiastic individuals to design, hand make and sell footwear in an industrial, cost effective way within the UK.

Cos K London is a small handmade footwear company who's aim is to establish UK based manufacturing. Our applicants will have the opportunity to make a perfectly crafted pair of shoes, learn how to set up their own workshop, and hand make footwear in the most cost effective way possible. The intention is to show how hand made footwear can be a successful industry and not just a hobby or craft. We want to teach the future entrepreneurs of the UK to manufacture the perfect handmade shoe, and give these enthusiasts a real understanding of the construction and production techniques required to achieve the perfection that goes into each pair. 

Cos K (our teacher) has 35 years of experience in making handmade, bespoke and production line footwear. He has been a major influence in the Fetish industry for over 3 decades and has worked closely with the couture fashion fratirnity.  He is the founder of several successful brands throughout these decades including Leatherworks, City Cobbler and now his most recent brand Fabulously Fetish.  He was also The Artist formerly known as Prince’s personal shoemaker for 9 years making his colourful fabric stiletto ankle boot.  His passion for breaking the boundaries in high heel making has truly influenced the modern world of shoes. Throughout the years, Cos K has found a way to balance the bespoke elements of shoemaking and factory based manufacturing process, and this is exactly what we will try to teach our students. With the gradual demise of the British shoe manufacturing over the last couple of generations, the shoemaking skills have been lost and the workforce is no longer available.  With your help we can change this. We believe that there are many young, talented, intelligent individuals who would very much like the opportunity to learn these skills and make successful careers for themselves in this wonderful industry. Lets make sure we give them the chance to do so and simultaneously re-build the much neglected industry that we love.

What We Need & What You Get

The amount of money we need to raise is £30,000. We have compiled the following list of perks that we are offering to our contributors:

-handmade key chain with our Cos.K London logo

-Free entry into our prize draw for a free pair of shoes

-lifetime 5% discount on all made to measure services

-lifetime 10% discount on all made to measure services

-lifetime 15% discount on all made to measure services

-lifetime  20% discount on all made to measure services

-1 day crash course in shoemaking 

-2 day crash course in shoemaking where you will take a pair of self made shoes home with you at the end of the course

-Free pair of made to measure shoes

Here is a breakdown of what we need the funding for:

Factory improvements for Health and safety compliance

Workshop renovations £2000

Machine repairs £1500

Safety gloves, masks, Footwear, aprons £200

Factory improvements for workshops

We will be separating the shoemaking course into five processes, so our students will learn easily how to compartmentalise their workload when working on a professional level. Each process will be separated into sections of the factory.  For each section of the factory we will need to buy machines and improve the quality of what we already have accessible to us.  Here is a breakdown of what we require:

Machinery

Our current workshop already has machines in place, however in order to make the class a complete experience for the students we will need to invest money on a wider range of machines.

-1 x  Clicking press £1500

-1 Back moulding machine £2500

-1 x splitting machine £3000

-4 x flash heaters @£700 = £2800

-4 x blow heater guns @£50= £200

-1 x wide band roughing machine £2500

-1 x roughing and finishing machine £2500

-4 x staple guns @£250 = £1000

-Compressor - £800

-Spray booth with extraction - £1000

-Automatic heeler - £2000

Equipment

-1 x Cutting board £500

Materials

Our aim at the end of the course is to have supplied our students with the materials and the know how to have produced during the course, a set of shoes that they can take with them to begin their own business.  For this we will need a range of lasts, heels, soles, leather and lining material.  Here is our breakdown:

Leather - £1000

Lining - £1000

Soles - £1000

Heels - £2000

Lasts - £1000

If we do not reach our target, the money we do raise will be spent on giving the students the most valuable experience possible, supplying them with the means to make their own shoes that they can take home with them and start to sell.  Also, it is most important to comply with health and safety acts and agreements.

The Impact

Your contributions will help us breed a new generation of quality shoemakers, who will learn to appreciate the need for attention to the finer details and turning the crafting of a shoe into an art.  Our long term aim is to encourage London based designers to base their production in the UK, and to promote a more personalised business network within the fashion industry.

With the necessary funding, we will be able to educate a generation of young talent to understand the importance of quality and aesthetics without either factor being compromised. We're here to help enthusiastic, aspiring entrepreneurs find their way.  The higher the final contribution, the more we can do to help kick start our students careers as either a start up brand, or as a bespoke designer.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that we cannot get support from everyone but we would really appreciate you taking an interest in this project and give us feedback on what you think about what we are doing.  Spreading the word about this project will help us achieve our ultimate goal which is keeping UK based manufacturing alive and to become the world respected industry it once was!  Help us reach the people who will propel this project to where it needs to be using the indiegogo sharing tools.

Thank you for reading and we look forward to updating you all on our progress!

story:
I love children, they are my greatest teachers. In my experience working with families, I have noticed a consistent theme: that harmony and health are relative to the levels of anxiety and balance in the home. Children absorb the world around them like sponges, and often have few coping tools necessary to navigate stressful situations. In this modern age, our environment is brimming with frequencies from wifi, cell phone towers, EMFs from electricity in our homes, constant drones of appliances or fans... the list goes on. The human body craves harmony. Based on physics and the Law of Resonance, we are resonant beings mentally, emotionally, and physically.  As these laws prescribe, the body will tune itself to its surroundings. 

My vision for Bring Harmony Home incorporates three parts to improving family cohesion:  1) Sound and Frequency therapy, 2) Mindfulness, and 3) Connective Communication. This work is designed for families with children who struggle with emotional sensitivities, as well as parents who wish to learn simple self-care techniques. With the funds raised, I will purchase a sound healing table integrated with speakers. These tables offer full body relaxation, improved circulation, a greater sense of peace and wellness, as well as a huge range of curative benefits for numbers of imbalances. Along with sessions on the table, families will receive tools to develop a personal mindfulness practice, strengthen uses of connective communication, and learn techniques to improve the relations of family members. 

My greatest wish is for all beings to be happy. Happiness is harmony in your home. Thank you for sharing in my vision and investing in the well-being of our future generations.

Here is a picture of the sound table, designed by Ray at Resocustic Harmony (http://www.resocusticharmony.com)


This is the table all packed up and ready for home visits!

I'm grateful for your time and energy you've shared towards my dream.  Thank you from the bottom of my heart!

May all beings be happy!

story:
Ola amigos de Npili!

Friends and supporters of Npili School campaign: We want to thank all of you who donated, shared encouraged and believed in us and the importance of this project in changing the future of marginalized and disadvantaged girls in Guinea-Bissau.


Your donation in this campaign goes directly to the Atena Foundation to finance part of cost related with this project. Financial Report of this project will be sent for those who have donated.

We will not be giving up on these girls and women, therefore the cancelation of the project is a no option.

Wish you all a prosperous year full of Love, Peace and Happiness

Online Npili School Project Volunteer team.
