story:
Grace Note Music Studio is a private-lessons based music school located in the downtown area of Visalia, California. We have served the community with the best opportunities for private music education since early 2014. Grace Note offers private instruction on nearly all musical instruments and voice, with highly skilled instructors who love teaching as much as they love music! We put on quarterly student recitals which help our students stay accountable for practicing, as well as to help them develop as young performing musicians. We are proud to provide a unique and comfortable atmosphere where everybody is welcome!

We are launching the Young Perfomers Scholarship so that we can provide lessons and instruments to students who could not otherwise afford them. The need in our community is very high and though we would love to sponsor many more students, we are starting with five scholarships and a long term goal of providing scholarships to more students in the future. Each scholarship will cover the cost of 12 months tuition ($2,500) and the cost of an instrument up to $500. This brings the total cost of each scholarship to $3,000. We get referrals for students in need of these scholarships from schools in our community and several local programs such as The Pro Youth Heart.

Please support our campaign in any way you can! If you are not able to contribute monetarily please spread the word by sharing our campaign with your friends and family. If you are able to contribute you will receive perks for contributions of $5 or more. Just know that anything you do to help our campaign will bring us closer to giving the gift of music education to five young members of our community. Who knows what great things these students will go on to do because of your generosity!

story:
Background

Cuellaje is a remote parish in the Andes Mountains of Ecuador.  The local school is comprised of approximately 400 students and English courses are mandatory.  Presently there are two English teachers that provide daily instruction to students of all grade levels.  There is a computer lab, but it is in high demand and often not available.  In addition, motivation to learn English is not very high.  This is partially due to the fact that there are not many opportunities to speak English. 

Most students plan to remain in the area and work on the local farms and do not have plans to study in university.  Because of this, there is not a great need for technical education and students can make a basic living without much education.  However, there are a handful of students who do have an interest in studying English and continuing their education in university.  Our goal is to provide the necessary resources and motivational strategies to encourage as many students as possible to follow this dream.

Goal: $7,000

We need to raise $7,000 to bring the English language into the classroom. Specifically, we are seeking: 

  • 4 Projectors (presently the whole school shares one). - $2000.00
  • 4 Chromebooks - $1500.00
  • English Workbooks & Interactive Video Lessons - $1200.00
  • Visual English, Science & Math Reference Posters - $300.00
  • Perks - $1600.00 (Supports the local Kichwa community!)
  • Indiegogo fees & card processing fees - approx. $400.00

Stretch Goal: $10,000

  • Scholarships (x2) + $1500.00 each
If we meet our funding for the initial resources listed above, we hope to create a greater incentive for learning English by establishing a scholarship for students to travel to the United States and live with a voluntary host family for a month.  Each scholarship will include the cost of travel from Cuellaje to the Capitol of Quito, as well as round-trip airfare to their host family in the United States.  Students will be chosen by the staff of "Unidad Educativa Cuellaje" based on a combination of performance and merit.

What You'll Get:

Hand-written Postcard - $2+

You'll receive a hand-written thank you postcard from our team!  Each postcard will feature images from Cuellaje and neighboring Otavalo.

Café Rio Intag - $12/$18

Beautifully aromatic shade-grown arabica coffee from the Intag Valley, in the Andes of Ecuador.  To top it all off, the local coffee industry is organized in a local association of growers, so farmers receive fair market value for their café.  Coffee is available in 1/2 lb. ($12) and 1 lb. ($18) packages.  Coffee is ground, roasted and ready for you to enjoy immediately!


Scarfs, Blankets, Ponchos, & Hammocks

The craftsmanship of the hand-made goods from the largely indigenous town of Otavalo, is well known throughout Ecuador.  You can choose between the beautiful scarfs, blankets, ponchos and hammocks purchased at market value, directly from the artisans who wove them.


Hand-loomed Scarf - $25

Hand-loomed scarf or shawl, made by Antonio Lema and purchased at full market value from his family in Otavalo.  Please specify whether you would like a scarf or a shawl and choose from a base color (blue, red, green, purple, orange, pink, random).  Scarfs are sewn together in a large continuous fabric that can be looped twice around the neck (as shown above).  Shawls are open and can be draped or wrapped around the neck (as shown above).  Patterns will be similar to, but potentially vary from the images above.

Hand-Woven Children's Poncho - $40

Hand-woven children's wool poncho, made by Zoila Teran and purchased at full market value from her family in Otavalo.  Choose from the earth tones pictured above (tan, brown, grey).  Ponchos will be similar to, but potentially vary slightly from the images above.

Hand-Woven Blankets - $50

Hand-woven blankets, made by Matilde Lema and purchased at full market value from her family in Otavalo.  Choose a base color (blue, red, green, purple, orange, pink) and patterns will be similar to but possibly vary slightly from the images above.

Hand-Woven Wool Poncho - $60

Hand-woven wool poncho, made by Zoila Teran and purchased at full market value from her family in Otavalo.  Ponchos will be similar to, but potentially vary slightly from the image above.

Hand-loomed Women's Poncho - $60

Hand-woven blankets, made by Veronica Muenala and purchased at full market value from her family in Otavalo.  Choose a color (red, white, blue, yellow) and patterns will be similar to but possibly vary slightly from the image above.
 


Hand-loomed Hammock - $75

Hand-woven blankets, made by Veronica Muenala and purchased at full market value from her family in Otavalo.  Choose a color (red, white, blue, yellow) and patterns will be similar to but possibly vary slightly from the image above.

Donate by Nov, 8th and receive your perk(s) with plenty of time for the holiday season!


A few examples of our handmade perks, as worn in NYC!



Thanks to all of our volunteer models at Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, New York!


The Impact

While volunteering in the schools in Cuellaje over the past summer, I was often asked by the English teachers, "What can I do to motivate my students?"  The truth is that there is not much reason for students to buy into their English language classes, or their education in general.  Very few English speakers visit Cuellaje and fewer locals move away.  Students in Cuellaje typically do not go on to university after grade school; generally they take up work on local farms and live very basically in or close to town.  

The objective behind this project is to provide the resources (projectors, computers, English workbooks and visual aides) and opportunities (English travel scholarships) that will motivate students to consider learning English, and external opportunities, such as university, to be a reality.  Your contributions will help us to achieve this and in return you will receive the highest quality hand-crafts the local indigenous Kichwa community have to offer.  In addition to the impact that you will make in the lives of the students of Cuellaje, you will also be supporting the local indigenous community of Otavalo and the coffee growers of the Intag Valley.


Risks & Challenges

Being an international project, there are considerable challenges with regards to pulling this off successfully.  They are laid out below along with the steps that are being taken to be successful in spite of them.

What happens if we don't reach our goal of $11,000?

Good question.  If we don't reach our goal, then we will use the money we have raised (minus the cost of perks) to provide the resources we can afford.  Laptops and projectors will be first priority, followed by visual classroom resources and English workbooks.  Keep in mind that any money this project receives is working two-fold to benefit the local indigenous Kichwa community of Otavalo as well as Unidad Educativa Cuellaje.  

How will you ensure that the resources will be used as intended?

This project is built in direct partnership with the school system in Cuellaje.  The English department, the Inspector and the School Director (Principal, essentially) are all invested in the success of this project and there are check and balances in place to keep all parties accountable in the use of the resources which we will provide.  On top of direct school involvement in the project, the regional cooperative in charge of education, agricultural opportunities and economic development programs is involved and actively spreading the word.

How will you manage the fulfillment of all of the perks?
We have partnered directly with Kichwa families around Otavalo that are capable of providing consistently high quality products.  A different family is dedicated to the production of each of the different products that we are offering.  As the orders come in, Rosita Rojas (native to Otavalo) will be placing them with each of the designated families.  Once they are ready, she will ship the orders to the United States and we will distribute directly to you from New York City.  All orders should be ready by the holiday season and would make beautiful gifts!


Other Ways You Can Help!

We understand that not everyone is in a position to help out with monetary contributions, but there are other ways that you can help.  Every person that shares this project online extends our reach to hundreds and potentially thousands of others; that's tremendous!  Please consider sharing our project with family and friends and imagine the opportunities that you can help create for the students of Cuellaje.

Mountains of Ecuador.  The local school
is comprised of approximately 400 students and English courses are
mandatory.  Presently there are two
English teachers that provide daily instruction to students of all grade
levels.  There
is a computer lab, but it is in high demand and often not available.  In addition, motivation to learn English is
not very high.  This is partially due to
the fact that there are not many opportunities to speak English. 
Most students plan to remain in the area and
work on the local farms and do not have plans to study in university.  Because of this, there is not a great need

story:
We’ll distribute GrowBook paperbacks and e-books at little or no cost to entrepreneurs where our world's extreme poverty is concentrated: Latin American, the Caribbean, Africa, and Asia. And we’ll train them to apply GrowBook's advice to mature their businesses and create desperately needed jobs.

Jobs fight poverty in US & developing countries:

Drawing on years of empowering domestic and international entrepreneurs, we just finished writing and editing the 200-page GrowBook in English for American entrepreneurs. Your donations will cover the cost of revising it for various cultural contexts, then translating, printing, and distributing various language editions.

GrowBook will be translated into languages in which business-building resources are scarce: Spanish (LatAm), Creole (Haiti), French (Africa), and Malayalam (India). Even where financial capital is available, intellectual capital is sorely lacking. Without plentiful examples of successful businesses or books to learn from, it's difficult for developing-world entrepreneurs to grow their businesses and generate new jobs. This “hand up” will raise the capacity of local business leaders to take care of their own communities. People everywhere need jobs that affirm their human dignity and allow them to provide education, healthcare, housing, and food to their families.

Integrated with ongoing mentoring and training:

GrowBook will be used by Creating Jobs Inc (and our partner organizations) to “mentor and train entrepreneurs to grow companies, create jobs, and help communities thrive.” Instead of just putting a book in their hands, we’ll use it in our ongoing training and mentoring programs, helping them to understand and apply it in their actual businesses. We’ll work with them to put into practice one chapter a month in our 24-month programs.


Here are some of our authors and mentors gathered to discuss plans for GrowBook.

About the book:

GrowBook is hard-won know-how from seasoned entrepreneurs – a quick-reference guide to activating the 24 essential drivers of small business success. Written by and for small business owners, GrowBook is filled with highly concentrated wisdom in a quick-scan format. This book isn’t about how to merely run a business; instead it advises the specific actions that drive success. We’ve bootstrapped successful businesses from nothing, so we know how to cut through the clutter and offer straight-up advice that works. Success isn’t easy, but it can be made simple.

Here are the chapter titles for the English edition:

Part One | Leadership

1.  Lead Yourself  

2.  Set the Course

3.  Pursue Goals

4.  Develop Systems  

5.  Innovate Constantly

Part Two | Market Position

6.  Craft Customer-Focused Branding

7.  Generate a Sufficient Flow of Customers

8.  Improve Google Rankings

Part Three | Production

9.  Create Unique Customer Solutions

10.  Produce Efficiently

Part Four | Sales & Service

11.  Close Sufficient High-Margin Sales

12.  Multiply Raving Fans

Part Five | Employees

13.  Develop Sales, Production & Office Leaders

14.  Engage Employees

15.  Build Teamwork

Part Six | Finance

16.  Achieve Positive Cash Flow

17.  Save Money Regularly

18.  Control Spending Closely

19. Negotiate Good Deals

20. Access Capital & Limit Debt

21.  Manage Major Risks

Part Seven | Giving Back

22.  Help Employees Grow

23.  Mentor Other Entrepreneurs

24.  Serve with Time, Talent & Treasure 

     Graduates of our training program in Honduras, who are now mentoring others.

What your Donations will Do:

$1,500 Setup costs – ISBNs, fonts, graphics, cover design, and marketing.

$3,000 ($4,500 total) English edition – formatting, printing, and shipping of 500 paperbacks and unlimited e-books. (All proceeds from the English edition will be reinvested to make GrowBook available in other languages.)

$7,500 ($12,000 total) Spanish edition used to mentor and train entrepreneurs in Latin American – includes cultural revisions, translation, formatting, printing, and shipping of 1,000 paperbacks and unlimited e-books.

$4,500 ($16,500 total) Creole edition used to mentor and train entrepreneurs in Haiti – includes cultural revisions, translation, formatting, printing, and shipping of 500 paperbacks and unlimited e-books.

$16,500 Goal

Stretch goal $7500 ($24,000 total) French edition used to mentor and train entrepreneurs in Africa – includes cultural revisions, translation, formatting, printing, and shipping of 1,000 paperbacks and unlimited e-books.

Stretch goal $7500 ($31,500 total) Malayalam edition used to mentor and train entrepreneurs in India – includes cultural revisions, translation, formatting, printing, and shipping of 1,000 paperbacks and unlimited e-books.

Stretch goal $7500 ($39,000 total) 1,500 more paperbacks in aforementioned languages for use in various countries.

Stretch goal $7500 ($46,500 total) Additional language editions – includes cultural revisions, translation, formatting, printing, and shipping of 1,000 paperbacks and unlimited e-books. (Donate $7500 to have GrowBook translated and distributed in the language of your choice!)

$30,000 Stretch Goals

Why Give?

Do Good. Your gifts are tax-deductible and will move our nonprofit towards its vision of “business for global good.” 100% of the profits from sales of the English edition will be reinvested to spread GrowBook across the developing world. The authors aren’t taking any royalties – we’d rather use those funds to raise the capacity of our friends who are creating jobs around the world. That makes us super happy! Click here to meet global entrepreneurs who’ve received some of the training now compiled in GrowBook.

Get Perks. See the right column for goodies that go to our funders. They include pre-release copies of the English edition of GrowBook in both paperback and e-book.

Email me with any questions: evan@creatingjobs.org

Thank you very, very much!

Evan Keller, Founder & Executive Director of Creating Jobs Inc.

PS: Please share this link on Facebook: http://igg.me/at/growbook

story:
Brittany has been accepted as a 

ONE WORLD GLOBAL FELLOW!


One World.


The One World Network of Schools believe that transformational schools will change the lives of children, prove the possible, and build a better tomorrow in all contexts, cultures and countries around the world. The  One World and KIPP Global Fellowship prepares fellows with a passion to establish transformational schools in developing countries by preparing them to cultivate leadership development, growing transformational schools and cross-pollinate knowledge-sharing, best practices and lessons learned over a three (3) month span in Houston, Texas.

"The One World and KIPP Global Fellowship program encompass my passion for school transformation through human-centered approaches that build on my experience in instructional design, education methodology consulting, project management, evaluation, research, and teacher training. " - Brittany

One Region.

Today, One World trains, supports and partners with highly motivated leaders in six countries (Mexico, Chile, South Africa, Israel, Indonesia and India) around the world to create excellent schools in high-need communities. The schools that have been established, continue to grow into thriving networks of like-minded schools that are all members of The One World Network of Schools

I am the first person from the Caribbean to be accepted to this fellowship!

"I am determined to establish a network of schools that cater to both  low-income and middle-income families across the Caribbean. I am confident this experience will equip me with both the skills and partnerships needed, to ensure that sustainable investment are made in Education within the region to grow transformational schools and trains school leaders". -Brittany 

One Goal: EDUCATION FOR ALL.

Let's face it -  Given market failures and equity concerns, the public sector remains an important player in providing education services, but making high-quality education accessible for all in developing countries like Jamaica requires innovative programs and initiatives in addition to public resources and leadership.  

"I plan to establish model schools that demonstrate the effectiveness of sustainable partnerships in education that provide tailored and targeted education services and approaches that improve the learning outcomes of various cultural groups within the national context." - Brittany


WHAT DO I NEED TO PURSUE THIS DREAM?

USD $25,000 for 10 WEEKS of FELLOWSHIP in HOUSTON, TEXAS.


  • If I reach my goal, all funds will be used as outlined above.
  • If I don't reach my goal, all donations will be used for the Public-Private Partnership Model School Transformation Project at The Boys' Town Infant & Primary School  in which I will be leading as CEO of the school in the 2016 school year.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share my campaign with anyone you think will want to contribute to the development of Education in Jamaica and the Caribbean at large.

Share your time and expertise at the schools in my network!

Thank you in advance,

Brittany!

I am the first person from the Caribbean to be accepted to this fellowship!
"I am determined to establish a network of schools that cater to both  low-income and middle-income families across the Caribbean. I am confident this experience will equip me with both the skills and partnerships needed, to ensure that sustainable investment are made in Education within the region to grow transformational schools and trains school leaders". -Brittany 





One Goal: EDUCATION FOR ALL.



Let's face it -  Given market failures and equity concerns, the
public sector remains an important player in providing education services, but
making high-quality education accessible for all in developing countries like
Jamaica requires innovative programs and initiatives in addition to public
resources and leadership.  

"I plan to establish model schools that demonstrate the effectiveness of sustainable partnerships in education that provide tailored and targeted education services and approaches that improve the learning outcomes of various cultural groups within the national context." - Brittany
  
WHAT DO I NEED TO PURSUE THIS DREAM? USD $25,000 for 10 WEEKS of FELLOWSHIP in HOUSTON, TEXAS.


  If I reach my goal, all funds will be used as outlined above.
If I don't reach my goal, all donations will be used for the Public-Private Partnership Model School Transformation Project at The Boys' Town Infant & Primary School  in which I will be leading as CEO of the school in the 2016 school year.


    Other Ways You Can Help
Share my campaign with anyone you think will want to contribute to the development of Education in Jamaica and the Caribbean at large.
Share your time and expertise at the schools in my network!
Thank you in advance,
Brittany!

story:
Nishmat’s over 100 certified Yoatzot Halacha working selflessly throughout Israel, North America, and the UK, have answered over 250,000 questions to- date. Bringing this halachic and medical expertise to women worldwide requires raising over $600,000 per year. Please partner with us to enable us to continue Ask the Yoetzet and our on-line resources to the end of 2015.

Nishmat’s Women's Health and Halacha Websites depend on your generous support to provide a female, halachic address 24/6:

  • Halachic questions answered in English, Hebrew, French and Spanish

  • Hundreds of vital medical-halachic articles, constantly updated 

  • Online interactive Kallah (bridal) classes and refresher course 

  • Website & App for Medical Professionals

What We Need:

  • $18,000 to continue answering questions and providing on-line services to women around the globe. 

The Impact

A friendly female halachic address for women worldwide. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign with your family & friends, and help us reach our goal.

story:
Help us! We want arrange libraries for 7 schools in Ghana and so create permanently support of education for current children but also for future generations! In the next at November we want to run the first year of competition in reading, recitation of poetry and prose (by using the books from these libraries) and reward the best of children on each school! Association Exit was founded in the year 2005 in Slovakia with goal to support and research education in ghanian schools. In 2006 we started with the child sponsorship of education with the project "My child in Africa".

 The most of the children which are included in this project are orphans or motherless children. After that in 2010 we run the first year of competion in writing and drawing and in 2011 the first sport competition. Continouosly we included 7 schools  to our projects - Ashamoah, Debora Vision, Kofi Donkor, Kwaku Pamfo, Kyekyewere, Nankase Asuom and Oduman Asuaba. The whole amount in these schools represents 2 095 children and 99 teachers. All schools are in the village and receive from goverment 10 - 15 books on learning every 5 years.  Many of children go some kilometres by foot to school every day to they could learn write, read, count, about nature or information technology and after learning they return back home and help in their families -  they care of sisters, brothers, help on the fields, bring the watter on theirs heads etc. They've got no pc or tablet, tv or radio, they haven't toys or sweets and always on your question: "What do you want?" their responses are the same: "Pen or paper", which they can use in the school for education. So much it means for them - one piece of the paper and you can imagine, what it means for them to have possibility to read the books, because they know that education can change and make better their life.

story:
Status Update: April 2015

Since our campaign finished in January 2015 we have been quite busy @ Chigumukire making progress on finishing the construction of our first little school block for the Standard 1 & 2 learners.


Attached below are some pictures of the work completed thus far since our campaign concluded: 

Inside plastering ✓ 

Window frames ✓


Door frames ✓

Outside plastering ✓

Conclusion of worked finished in February 2015
Inside/Outdoor Plastering
 Installation Door & Window Frames

Installation of Doors ✓ 

Installation of Window Panels ✓ 


Conclusion of worked finished in March 2015
Inside/Outdoor Plastering 
 Installation Door & Window Frames

Inside classroom floors ✓ 

Outside classroom steps ✓ 

Outside trim plastering ✓

Conclusion of worked finished in April 2015
Inside/Outdoor flooring & steps for both classrooms
Outside Plastering Building Trim
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Welcome!




My name is Luis, and I thank you for taking the time to drop by our little school building campaign!

¿Whats going on here?

I am raising money to finish building a Jr Primary School block for Standards 1 - 2 in the rural fishing community of Chigumukire, Senga Bay, Malawi.

¿Who am I?

I am just one person who cares to make a small difference in the lives of those less fortunate.  

I have spent the past 3 years working directly with community leaders and government educators to develop and successfully delivery "Small Footprint, Large Impact" educational projects in Malawi. 



All my projects have a sustainable end, which is to empower people to empower themselves, and I believe firmly that the best way to do this is at the educational level.


¿So what is the project goal?

Malawi is one of the poorest nations on earth, and education is substandard. The government sadly does not have the appropriate means to maintain nor further develop its educational infrastructural in order to meet  population needs. 

Our goal is enrich "on-time" education enrollment for learners in at risk rural communities such as Chigumukire whom don´t have access to a nearby school.  

¿What will happen when you finish the school?

Once development is finished, our school block project will be handed over to the Community School Committee and the Malawi Board of Education/Salima TDC for administration in the governments public schools program as a sister school to Senga Bay Primary. 

Where are we now? 

As of October 10th 2014 we have finished about 85% of our first block

NOW WE NEED YOUR HELP

Funds raised will be used directly towards purchasing the following:

(Stage 1) Materials for construction:

  • 25x 50kg bags of Portland & 15x 50kg bags of Kumanga grade cement.
  • 2x Hardwood door frames, 2x doors, 2x door knob lock sets, 2x deadbolts, 6 hardwood window frames, 1x roll of fine mesh screen, 4x Plywood boards, and 1ltr black paint in order to install two new blackboards in both classrooms.
  • 12 6x2 Planks for creating sitting stools, classroom shelf's, and small table legs.

(Stage 2) Materials for classrooms:

  • Basic learning supplies such as chalk, pencils, schoolbooks and notebooks.
  • Some educational themed posters and learning based props to visually stimulate the children (i.e, Geographical Maps, ABCs & 123s Posters, Etc).

    All project labor is pooled through appointed local community volunteers,thus ensuring an elevated sense of community ownership. 



By supporting our project today you will not only empower us to finish building the first block of our jr primary school, but we´ll also be able to use the block as a community service area running awareness programs that aim to tackle such issues as HIV/AIDS and Malaria which are widespread in Malawi as a whole.

 
 The community leaders and I thank you for taking the time to read through our campaign.
For more information on my story, and/or to see chronicled updates on our project progress, please kindly give our FB page a "Like"   

https://www.facebook.com/TheChigumukireSchoolProject

or check out our webspage:  

www.ourschoolproject.tk

Thank you once again for your loving support,
and have a wonderful new year in 2015!


Warm blessings,
Luis E. Vazquez Jimenez
Project Sponsor
Senga Bay, Chigumukire, Malawi

story:
Peace Corps Iran Association is a nationwide organization representing the 1,748 Peace Corps volunteers who served in Iran in the 1960’s and 70’s, aiming to preserve the legacy of PC Iran and promote mutual understanding among Americans and Iranians.

In May, 2015, we are bringing members, Iranian Americans, students, and the general public to Austin, Texas, for Iran Today, Quest for New Narratives. Hosted at, and co-sponsored by The University of Texas at Austin's Center for Middle Eastern Studies, this 3-day event will highlight the diversity and complexity of Iranian society, its historical legacy, and prospects for the future. We’ll explore opportunities for improved relations between Americans and Iranians.

Confirmed speakers include William O. Beeman, Mary Catherine Bateson, Hamid Naficy, Michael Hillmann, Mary Elaine Hegland, and Ambassador John Limbert. A Cultural Bazaar will bring to life Iran’s creative arts and entertainment, including a featured performance of the Peace Cylinder Project.

We are raising money for scholarships to pay the registration fee for 30 people who might otherwise be unable to attend. We are excited to offer as perks, copies of books published by several members about their Peace Corps experiences. We also offer a complementary PCIA membership to all who contribute, and to our highest level donors, a free conference registration or two.

We’ve already presented amazing conferences in Portland (2011) and Boston (2013). You can be part of this one by contributing to our campaign! Help us create bonds of understanding with the Iranian people and build new narratives in today’s world. Please share our campaign with your friends, donate, and join us in Austin in May! More conference information here:  www.peacecorpsiran.org.

story:
Hello, everybody!!

My name is Felicity Kiser. I'm 21 years old, the second oldest of nine home-schooled children. I have a passion for recipes, cupcakes, music, stories, needlework, and anything to do with archaeology and treasure hunting. I've always been enchanted by stories of the Titanic, the Tombs and Pyramids, Dinosaurs, Pompeii, Troy.... The accomplishments, the legends, the tragedies, and the mysteries of civilizations. Our past's secrets that have been discovered like new memories. 

I believe history is necessary for the enrichment and inspiration of our future, and I see archaeology as a portal into history; so that we do not only have stories and legends, but a palpable  connection to our past. It is an almost magical feeling to touch what others have touched, to look upon what others have seen, and to stand where we know other have stood long centuries before we even existed.  

I'm from a very small town in Texas, steeped in old-timey tradition and rich in history, home of Fort Richardson and one of the Lost Battalions of The Buffalo Soldiers. From my early childhood on into my teens, I spent hours in the dirt with my soup spoons and garden spades, hoping upon hope that I might find 'buried treasure' in the form of musket balls, pottery, beads, bones, or arrowheads. Anything to give the stories a little bit of life. All that time it has been a dream of mine to someday participate in a real dig. Well, I finally have my chance!! I recently discovered the online website belonging to The Archaeological Institute of America, and I submitted an application to participate as a volunteer on two of their digs in Romania this summer. Three days ago, I received their letter of acceptance. Needless to say, I'm practically giddy with excitement!!!  One of the projects will focus mainly on the excavation of a Roman 'Villa Rustica' (one of these), and the second on the excavation of Roman Castrum (Legionary Encampments/ Encampment sites). Mega-awesomness, right?? You can see more info for what we'll be doing here and here. It' a ten week trip, living part-time with local families, working five days per week, and exploring on the weekends (Dracula's castle, anyone? Muahahaha! )While in Romania, I plan to keep a journal and scrapbook, complete with an account of my daily adventures and thoughts, poetry, photos of the rich surrounding countryside, local recipes, legends, and lore, all of which I will publish upon my return. I think that this would be very educational for me, a great practice of discipline, cooperation, and social interaction, and a fabulous cultural experience. 

Those of you who help to fund my trip, depending on the level of your contribution, will receive either a postcard, a souvenier, a copy of my book, or a combination of all of the above. I have 28 days to pay the entry fee in full, otherwise permission for my participation will be withdrawn, so please donate and/or share!!! A portion of your donation also goes towards plane and train fare, as well as a small emergency fund. $7500 is the bare-bones minimum I need to make this trip a success!

If it so happens that I do not reach my goal, the funds that I do receive will be put into savings towards my winter missionary field-service in Madagascar with Mercyships. Either way, I can promise that your money is being put to good use. Thanks a bunch!! Muah!

story:
What We Need & What You Get

My name is Ken Clark. I can remember when I was 8 years old and being woken in the dead of night by the shrill whistle of a distant locomotive. I would stand on my bed and watch as a great light in the distance slowly grew ever larger. As the train passed from across the river and the whistle blew from behind that great white light, I'd wonder where that freight train was going, what it was hauling, and that one day, I'd be going to interesting places, too. Since then, I've done many things, travelled to many countries for a variety of reasons and experienced incredible highs and extremely deep lows by what confronted me in those countries and peoples I met. Very soon I'll be going to Maasai Land in Kenya and I'm asking you to join me in doing some very much needed, very good work.

I'm asking for your help in funding the EWASO MEDICAL CLINIC deep in the heart of Maasai Land in the Great Rift Valley of Kenya. A uniquely indigenous people, the nomadic pastoralist Maasai Tribe is impoverished, mostly from circumstances beyond their control, and as such suffer greatly from a whole host of ailments: from the common childhood diseases such as measles and whooping cough to the more serious such as polio, meningitis, hepatitis A & E and HIV/Aids. Among other more exotic ailments that run rampant within this group of gentle, kindly people are malaria, tuberculosis, cholera, typhoid, meningitis and polio. Even the common cold is a killer. Half of all children born to the Maasai die before the age of two. A child is not recognized as such until 3 moons have passed. This is because of the incredibly high mortality rate - a result due to the lack of medicine and accessibility to basic preventive medical care. Something we all take for granted, yet a miracle to others less fortunate. $5000 is the set goal to supply vaccines, medicines, preventive care, medical supplies and hope to the Maasai Tribe of Kenya. Will you help?

The EWASO MEDICAL CLINIC is located 75 kilometers (about 47 miles) west of Nairobi in the heart of Maasai Land. It has only one staff member, Doctor Merue, a former government senior medical officer who quit his job and returned to serve the needs of his community. The clinic serves over 50 patients a day. 5000 Maasai live in the area which is very hot and unfertile. Clean water is only a dream. People walk between 5 and 30 kilometers (3 to 18 miles) to the clinic every day to receive basic medical care and more.

This is an opportunity to reach out and touch a culture, a tribe, another human being in desperate need in a substantial way and offer the hope and healing they deserve. Will you help? Any amount, no matter how small, goes a long way.

100% of your contributions go to supply the EWASO MEDICAL CLINIC with antibiotics, vaccines, cough medicines and suppressants, anti-diarrhea medication, bandages, gauze pads, surgical supplies - in essence, all that you would hope to find in an isolated rural medical clinic. This is practical,  hands-on, lifesaving contributing. You are guaranteed to help save lives.

For your donation, you in turn not only receive the satisfaction of having saved a life and help preserve a unique culture, but also, depending on the amount of your contribution, you can receive anywhere from a 'Shout Out' to 'Lots Of Cool Stuff' described in the contribution section. And if that isn't enough, if you have an even greater heart for the destitute among the Maasai, the perks mentioned herein could be 'hand-delivered' to your door by me, and possibly my lovely wife, along with dinner at a local eatery of your choosing.

So will you help contribute today? If you can't do so financially, can you help get the word out to your family, friends and co-workers? Remember, 100% of your donation goes to the EWASO MEDICAL CLINIC. Spread the word! Please use the INDIEGOGO 'share tools' on this site. No matter how much or little, every bit helps!

I thank you, Dr. Merue thanks you and the Maasai Tribal Peoples of Kenya thank you.

100% of your contributions go to supply the EWASO MEDICAL CLINIC with antibiotics, vaccines, cough medicines and suppressants, anti-diarrhea medication, bandages, gauze pads, surgical supplies - in essence, all that you would hope to find in an isolated rural medical clinic. This is practical,  hands-on, lifesaving contributing. You are guaranteed to help save lives.
For your donation, you in turn not only receive the satisfaction of having saved a life and help preserve a unique culture, but also, depending on the amount of your contribution, you can receive anywhere from a 'Shout Out' to 'Lots Of Cool Stuff' described in the contribution section. And if that isn't enough, if you have an even greater heart for the destitute among the Maasai, the perks mentioned herein could be 'hand-delivered' to your door by me, and possibly my lovely wife, along with dinner at a local eatery of your choosing.
So will you help contribute today? If you can't do so financially, can you help get the word out to your family, friends and co-workers? Remember, 100% of your donation goes to the EWASO MEDICAL CLINIC. Spread the word! Please use the INDIEGOGO 'share tools' on this site. No matter how much or little, every bit helps!
I thank you, Dr. Merue thanks you and the Maasai Tribal Peoples of Kenya thank you.

story:
40 HOURS AND A BIKE

   YOUTH DEVELOPEMENT & EARN A BICYCLE       PROGRAM

              As a sophmore at Morehouse College I received a tool that would help me gauge the health and wellbeing of my life. This tool was a bicycle and I got it for only $25 from Sopo Bicycle Co-operative. I would ride this bicycle from East Atlanta to Morehouse College daily and I realized that riding a bicycle was a practical and engaging way to guide youth to become budding civil leaders, cyclist, and agriculturalist. All I had to do was get them on wheels. I started a bicycle shop out of my garage and kept it their for 2 years even through the birth of my first child Ezra Deangelo "The Helping Angel". In this garage we guided 75 youth through our pilot earn-a-bike program that helped rejuvenate the Ashview community garden and community association. 

                40 Hours and a Bike is a youth development program that rewards participants with a bicycle, health, economic, agricultural, and cycling education in return for completing the community engaging course. It is a program catered to Wecycle Atlanta’s key promotional objectives: 

Work Ethic

Health

Environment

Economics

Leadership

Sustainability

(Also known as the W.H.E.E.L.S. model)

Wecycle Atlanta makes these developmental objectives dually applicable through the cycling and agricultural components of the program. The outcome is a knowledgeable cyclist, budding agriculturalist, civically involved community member, and a youth educated on healthy and sustainable life practices. 

The program is broken down into the following course:

10 hours: Agricultural Education and Cooperative Service

10 hours: Bicycle maintenance course

10 hours: Safe cycling course

10 hour:  Advocacy Project

Within all of our courses the participants will be engaged in the W.H.E.E.L.S model. The course spans two weeks in which the bicycles are presented to the youth in the beginning of the program so that students will get to enjoy ownership of their bicycle Participants will learn and work with their bicycle through the program. Upon the completion of the program the bicycle is rewarded to the 40 Hours and a Bicycle participant. 


Agricultural Education and Cooperative Service:

       To highlight the W.H.E.E.L.S. model, WeCycle Atlanta guides youth on bicycles rides to local farms and gardens that serve as agricultural educational sites that youth gain access while learning to grow food. The participants of the program aid the community by helping cultivate fresh produce often scarce within the greater Westside of Atlanta. Through their service work they will be helping sustain a regenerative community asset created directly to improve the health of local constituents. 

While participating in the service, Wecycle 

Atlanta’s trained agricultural staff will teach 

participants:

- Lessons's on sowing seeds

- Use basic garden tools

- Plot options and growing techniques

- Basic growing conditions

- The economic and health benefits of locally grown food.

- The Farm to Table and Farm to Consumer Process

        Students will build, plant, taste, and create their way through an engaging course that will reinforce participants to participate in a healthy and community focused sustainable practice.

Bicycle Maintenance:

On staff Wecycle Atlanta has experienced mechanics that will teach the

participants the inner workings of their bicycles. Participants will become 

knowledgeable about basic tool usage and maintenance procedures such as changing tires, adjusting and replacing breaks and derailleur cables, and how to execute an ABC Quick Check. 

      Participants will then apply their mechanical skills to lead bicycle safety checks during weekly community rideStudents will then lead mechanical quick checks on Wecycle Atlanta Community Rides. Students will be introduced in a career of engineering and civil construction through their use of tools under the guidance of seasoned mechanics. 

Bicycle Safe Cycling Course

Wecycle Atlanta takes participants through a full course on bicycle safety, and handling skills. Our goal is to help develop a confident, and capable cyclist. 

A) Bicycling Skills 123 Youth is composed of 13 stations that satisfy the needs of children who are learning better bicycling handling skills.

1) Welcome Station

 2) Helmet Station

 3) Bike inspection Station

 4) Activity Station 1-4

Start/Stop and Straight Line

Hazard and Avoidance

Scan, Signal, Turn

Turning, Yielding

5) Activity Station 5-7

Entering the road

Along the road and sidewalk

Intersections

 6) Activity Station 8:  Practice as if in Traffic

 7) Activity Station 9:  Fun and Games

B) Riding Safety Program 

   Through the Riding Safety Program we hope to increase the safety of youth bicyclists, increase the number and frequency of children bicycling , and improve the lives of children. This curriculum engages youth through multimedia and practical bicycling activities, empowering them to travel effectively, independently, and make sensible and informed  decisions.

       This program is divided into three levels. Each progressive level provides more in-depth learning and greater opportunity for students to practice and apply safety knowledge in real-life scenarios. Each level requires increased expertise, time, and resources to effectively implement. 

Level 1: Classroom  

Level 2: Parking lot drills  

Level 3: Riding in a group on a guided bike tour with instructors and ride leaders

Advocacy 

In the bicycle advocacy program students get to choose a project that focuses on promoting cycling or agricultural. Students will engage in one of the following advocacy outlets to promote and/or sustain a sustainable environment for the communities they reside in. 

WHY DONATE? 
WE MUST GROW. Wecycle Atlanta Inc. currently resides in a 1,100 square bicycle shop in the West End. We store 400 + Bicycle in 4 Different locations and we need a larger facility to engage more youth and to be of better service to the community. It is difficult to operate with our inventory spread through the city of Atlanta. We currently take in 4 Kids a month and we'd like to take in 20 a month, but our space will not permit. We are also short of staff to aid in our programming. We'd like to higher youth counselors and train them to be certified program facilitators. 

WE BELIEVE. We believe that there are life and community changing possibilities when engaging youth in community on bicycles and getting them practicing the two W.H.E.E.L.S. of cycling and urban agriculture.

We also believe that engaging youth in stress relieving and healthy habits, such as cycling and gardening, can lead to positive social outcome for at-risk youth. 

Wecycle Atlanta Inc. is a proactive solution to obesity, education, and civil engagement. We believe that with the proper funding we can guide more youth down the right path on W.H.E.E.L.S. 

WE ACHIEVE. Here what they are saying about Wecycle Atlanta and our Founder Shawn Walton in the Community: 

"Wecycle Atlanta is Changing The World" - Complex Magazine

"Modern Man" - Black Enterprise Magazine

"The Community's Pulse" - The Next Big Thing Movement

"Cycling Kids Towards Better Health" - Atlanta Journal Constitution 

"Wecycle Atlanta is an Innovation Within The Food Industry" - Zagat

IT'S YOU WE NEED. We can't do this without you. Wecycle Atlanta views the solution to all things to be a circle. Let's take this simple bicycle wheel analogy. We recognize that without all of the points connected and engaged the circle can't move forward. We know that we are headed in the right direction and we need all do-gooders progressing the circles of community, health, and innovation to donate and HELP US GET MORE YOUTH ON W.H.E.E.L.S.
